title: This new AI tool helps Walmart’s merchandising team plan what’s in stores
summary:
• Walmart introduced Wally, an internal generative AI tool for its merchandising team to quickly analyze data and create reports.
• Wally can determine product details without the need for precise terminology, making data inquiries easier for merchants.
• The tool reportedly saves time for merchants and improves data accessibility, having been introduced to them about a month ago.

title: This VC looks deep into deeptech
summary:
- Antares Ventures, led by Michael Gryseels, focuses on deeptech startups addressing major challenges in Southeast Asia and India.
- The firm is most interested in late seed to series B investments; series A is their sweet spot.
- Singapore’s deeptech funding hit a five-year low in 2024, leading the government to pledge US$324 million to attract more VC investments.
- Indian deeptech startup Probus raised US$5 million in a series A1 round to enhance energy management solutions.

summary:
- Fortnite Chapter 6: Season 2, dubbed "Lawless", features a heist theme with new gameplay elements like bank vaults and armored car robberies.
- Introduces new locations including "Crime City" and features like gold water for powers and a fictional cryptocurrency.
- A new battle pass includes themed criminals and ties to Cowboy Bebop with specific quests starting March 1st.

title: Microsoft Prepares for Launch of GPT-4.5 and GPT-5 Models
summary:
- Microsoft engineers are preparing server capacity for OpenAI’s GPT-4.5 and GPT-5 models.
- GPT-4.5 is expected to launch in weeks, with Microsoft anticipating hosting as early as next week.
- OpenAI plans to release GPT-5 in late May, promising significant technological advancements.
- GPT-5 aims to unify OpenAI’s technologies, incorporating the new o3 reasoning model.
- Upcoming AI announcements from Microsoft are expected around the Build developer conference in May.

title: OpenAI Launches Operator AI Agent While Y Combinator Startup Firecrawl Seeks AI Employee
summary:
- Firecrawl, a Y Combinator startup, posted a job ad seeking an AI agent for autonomous app development with a salary range of $10,000 to $15,000.
- Founders view the job ad as a PR stunt to attract skilled AI engineers, and it's believed to be the first AI agent job posting on the YC job board.
- 50 applicants were received, but none met standards, leading to plans for a relaunch of the job posting.
- OpenAI rolled out Operator, an AI agent for ChatGPT Pro subscribers, in several countries including Australia, Brazil, Canada, India, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, and the U.K.
- Operator is not available in the EU and was originally launched in the U.S. in January 2025, capable of tasks like booking tickets.
- Access to Operator requires a $200/month ChatGPT Pro subscription and is available through a dedicated webpage.
- Competitors to Operator include Google, Anthropic, and Rabbit, each offering similar functionalities.

title: China expands AI education with DeepSeek
summary:
- Chinese universities are integrating AI courses utilizing technology from Hangzhou-based startup DeepSeek.
- Shenzhen University has launched an AI course featuring DeepSeek’s models, addressing crucial topics including security, privacy, and ethics.
- Other institutions like Zhejiang University, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, and Renmin University are also adopting DeepSeek’s AI for education and campus management.
- These initiatives align with China’s national action plan to establish a high-quality education system by 2035, released in January.

title: Xiaohongshu downloads drop as TikTok doubles on iPhone return
summary:
- TikTok's downloads more than doubled after being reinstated on Apple and Google stores.
- In contrast, rival app Xiaohongshu, also known as Rednote, experienced a 91% decline in downloads during the same period.
- Despite the drop in downloads, Xiaohongshu's daily active users remain about 25% higher than before TikTok's removal.

title: Substack Expands Video Features and Monetization for Creators
summary:
- Substack allows creators to monetize videos and publish them directly from the app.
- Creators can reach audiences and monetize without relying on algorithms.
- Future plans include teaser videos for free subscribers and new editing tools.
- Video adoption has grown significantly since 2022, with revenue for video creators increasing 2.5 times faster than non-video creators.
- By February 2025, 82% of top creators are expected to use audio and video, with a rising number of subscribers willing to pay for such content.
- Substack enables mobile uploads and monetization of video posts directly from the app.
- The platform provides tools to track post views, new subscribers, and revenue impact, with plans for customizable paywalls.
- The $20 million Creator Accelerator Fund encourages creators to join Substack without revenue loss.
- Live Video features have been expanded for all publishers on the platform.

title: Danish Astronaut Criticizes Musk's Claims About Biden and ISS Astronauts
summary:
- Elon Musk claims Biden intentionally abandoned astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams on the ISS for political reasons.
- Danish astronaut Andreas Mogensen refutes Musk's claims, calling it a lie and questioning Musk’s honesty.
- Wilmore and Williams were to return on SpaceX Crew-9 after a change in mission plans caused by thruster issues with Boeing Starliner.
- Crew-9 launch was originally scheduled for February but delayed to March due to preparations for Crew-10.
- Mogensen reminded Musk that the return plan has been in place since September.

sources.title: Danish Astronaut Criticizes Musk's Claims About Biden and ISS Astronauts

title: Estonia's Tech Sector Enhances Defense Startups and Baseten Secures $75M Funding
summary:
- xAI is in talks to raise [$10 billion](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/14/elon-musks-ai-company-xai-said-to-be-in-talks-to-raise-10b/), targeting a valuation of $75 billion.
- Fundraising includes investors like Sequoia Capital and Andreessen Horowitz.
- Successful funding would bring xAI's total capital to $22.4 billion.
- xAI plans to buy over $5 billion in servers for AI development, particularly for Grok models.
- Grok 3, the next chatbot version, is expected to outperform competitors and is set for release soon.
- xAI was previously valued at $51 billion after securing $6 billion in 2024.
- xAI aims to compete with OpenAI with Grok integrated into Musk’s platform X.

- Baseten, a San Francisco-based AI startup, raised **$75 million**, achieving a valuation of **$825 million**.
- The funding round was led by **IVP** and **Spark Capital**.
- Founded in **2019**, Baseten deploys AI models using cloud infrastructure from **Amazon** and **Google**.
- The company has reported a **sixfold revenue increase** over the past year and serves over **100 enterprises**.
- Baseten supports AI tools like **DeepSeek’s R1 reasoning model**, launched in **January**.
- The firm has around **60 employees** and competes with companies like **Together AI**.

- Estonia and eastern European nations are increasing investments in defense tech post-Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in 2022.
- Estonia leverages its tech industry to support defense startups, benefiting from geographical proximity to Russia.
- European defense tech investments grew from 0.4% to 1.7% of total VC, totaling nearly $1 billion between 2022 and 2024.
- Central and eastern Europe have seen a threefold increase in defense funding rounds since the conflict began.
- Estonia facilitates quick collaborations with frontline units focusing on military tech in private ventures.

title: Temu expands data collection from Korean users
summary:
- Temu updates privacy policy for Korean users effective February 21.
- The platform now collects additional personal data such as addresses, phone numbers, transaction amounts, and personal customs clearance codes.
- Users must consent to sharing their data with 27 third-party companies across six countries, including Korea, the US, and Singapore.
- The update follows scrutiny over data collection practices by foreign tech companies in South Korea.
- Last year, investigations were launched into platforms like Temu and AliExpress, with AliExpress fined for privacy violations.
- A decision regarding Temu from Korea's Personal Information Protection Commission is expected soon.

- This is the startup's first institutional funding since it was founded in 2021.
- The startup has developed a chatbot to assist physicians, currently used by a quarter of US doctors, that is trained exclusively on peer-reviewed medical journals.
- The funds will be used for strategic partnerships and to expand adoption in the healthcare sector.

- Trained on 100,000 character videos, the model is applicable for entertainment and advertising.

title: ‘It’s like their escape’: Retro gaming is back thanks to Gen Z
summary:
- Retro gaming is revived, particularly among Gen Z, with 24% owning retro consoles.
- A survey by Pringles shows 66% of Britons bought retro tech in the last two years.
- Popular retro consoles include Game Boy, Super Nintendo, and original Xbox, all discontinued years ago.
- 89% of gamers find retro games a break from the internet; 74% find them relaxing.
- A Retro Console Clinic by Pringles in London offered free repairs and encouraged retro gaming.
- 78% enjoy using retro gadgets to avoid smartphones; 21% of Gen Z wish smartphones never existed.
- The nostalgia trend continues to grow, with significant engagement on platforms like TikTok.

summary:

- This initiative follows reports of disputes at Supercharger stations due to limited ports frustrating EV drivers.

title: Fintech firm Block’s stock falls as Q4 earnings miss
summary:
- Block Inc. reported lower-than-expected Q4 earnings, causing a 6% drop in stock during after-hours trading.
- Adjusted earnings per share were US$0.71, missing the projected US$0.87.
- Revenue was US$6.03 billion, below the forecast of US$6.29 billion, but up 4.5% year-over-year.
- Gross profit rose 14% to US$2.31 billion, with gross payment volume exceeding expectations at US$61.95 billion.
- Block forecasts a 15% gross profit increase in 2025, projecting US$10.22 billion.

title: Clearview AI CEO Hoan Ton-That Resigns Amid Legal Challenges
summary:
- Hoan Ton-That, CEO of Clearview AI, resigned, stating it is time for the next chapter in his life.
- Clearview AI now has co-CEOs: Hal Lambert and Richard Schwartz, aiming to leverage new opportunities.
- The company faces numerous legal challenges and GDPR fines exceeding $100 million but has achieved high growth and revenue in 2024.
- Ton-That will remain on the board, and no specific reason was given for his departure.
- Clearview AI's 30 billion photo database faces criticism and legal challenges regarding privacy violations.
- Despite claims of growth, the company is unprofitable, with a valuation of US$130 million following its last funding round in 2021.

title: Nikola's Bankruptcy: Auctioning Business Amidst $1 Billion Debt
summary:
- Electric trucking startup Nikola aims to sell its business by April following its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.
- The company has at least three interested buyers and plans to solicit more bids by late March.
- If no full buyer is found, Nikola will consider selling off assets to address over $1 billion in liabilities.
- CEO Stephen Girsky mentioned previous attempts to find buyers, with various negotiations ultimately failing.
- A hearing on potential sales is expected in April, with the urgency due to Nikola's limited cash reserves of around $47 million.
- Nikola plans to sell its entire business by April 2025 after filing for chapter 11 bankruptcy with over $1 billion in liabilities.
- At least three potential buyers have shown interest; the bidding deadline is set for March 27 with an auction planned by month’s end.
- If no buyer is found, Nikola will sell assets individually, including its Coolidge, Arizona manufacturing facility.
- The company struggled to secure buyers or investors, with CEO Stephen Girsky revealing failed talks with 22 potential buyers.

title: Meta Launches Community Notes and Warns About Romance Scams Ahead of Valentine's Day
summary:
- Meta Platforms warns users about rising romance scams ahead of Valentine’s Day.
- Scammers impersonate attractive individuals using fake photos.
- Collaboration with Graphika to dismantle prevalent romance scams targeting individuals in Africa.
- Testing facial recognition tools for identifying fake profiles currently limited to celebrity impersonation.
- Users advised to verify identities before engaging or sending money.
- Acceptance of sign-ups for Community Notes on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads.
- Users over 18 with accounts older than six months can contribute.
- Contributors submit Notes with links and a 500-character limit.
- Notes require agreement from users who usually disagree for publication.
- Full rollout of Community Notes planned in the U.S. with no international expansion date yet.
- Mark Zuckerberg cites need for more unrestricted online speech.

- Meta has launched sign-ups for community notes on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads, replacing its third-party fact-checking program.
- The program allows U.S. users to add context to misleading posts with eligibility requiring a six-month-old account, verification, and age 18+.
- Contributors can submit 500-character notes with sources; these will be published if deemed helpful by users with differing views.
- Notes must follow community standards, and the rollout is currently U.S.-only.

sources.title: This Valentine’s Day, don’t fall for romance scams, Meta warns

title: Tesla and Google Expand Operations in India
summary:
- Google is planning to open its first physical retail stores outside the U.S. in India.
- The company is considering locations in New Delhi and Mumbai, with plans for 15,000 square feet stores.
- Expected opening timeline is at least six months, aiming to replicate Apple's store success in India.
- Google has invested $10 billion in India, focusing on it as a key growth market.
- Tesla plans to ship thousands of electric vehicles (EVs) to India, starting near Mumbai in the coming months.
- Sales are expected to begin in New Delhi, Mumbai, and Bengaluru by the third quarter of 2025.
- Cars will be sourced from Tesla’s German factory due to India's import duty concerns.
- Ongoing negotiations for a local factory to take advantage of EV policy incentives, including reduced import duties.

title: Grab's Future: AI, Automation, and Maybe No Drivers? + Mercor Raises $100M at $2B Valuation
summary:
- Mercor, an AI recruiting startup founded by three 21-year-old Thiel Fellows, raised $100 million in a Series B round.
- The funding round values Mercor at $2 billion, eight times its previous valuation.
- Felicis led the investment, with participation from existing investors including Benchmark, General Catalyst, and DST Global.
- Mercor's platform automates hiring with resume screening, candidate matching, AI interviews, and payroll management.
- The system claims to remove bias from hiring processes, which is a debated topic in AI.
- Mercor now has a $75 million annual revenue run rate (ARR) with significant growth in demand for various professionals.
- The company helps identify job roles for humans in an AI-driven economy, emphasizing the importance of expert hiring.

- Grab's shares fell 10% after its 2024 earnings announcement due to revenue forecast for 2025 falling short of analysts' estimates.
- 2024 revenue increased by 19% compared to 2023, and Grab achieved positive adjusted EBITDA for the first time, with net loss narrowing by 67%.
- CEO Anthony Tan announced active discussions with regulators in Southeast Asia regarding the company's plans in AI and autonomous vehicles (AVs).
- Grab's mobility business reported a 20% year-on-year rise in revenue and a 22% increase in adjusted earnings.
- Tan emphasized the long-term opportunities of AV technology and stated Grab's role in the transition to a hybrid AV-human fleet, suggesting that human drivers will not be immediately displaced.

sources.title: Mercor, an AI recruiting startup founded by 21-year-olds, raises $100M at $2B valuation
Grab’s Future: AI, Automation, and Maybe No Drivers?

title: FTC Investigates Tech Platforms for Censorship and Moderation Policies
summary:
- The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) announced a public inquiry into censorship by tech platforms, seeking comments from affected users.
- FTC Chairman Andrew Ferguson emphasized the need to understand potential legal violations by these firms regarding user silencing and intimidation.
- The inquiry coincides with social media companies loosening restrictions on hate speech, raising questions about the relation between content moderation and the First Amendment.
- Legal experts argue that the inquiry might misinterpret the First Amendment, which restricts government interference with speech, not private companies.
- President Trump signed an executive order making independent regulators accountable to the White House, potentially affecting the FTC's inquiry.
- The FTC launches an inquiry into content moderation practices of online platforms including Meta and Uber.
- The examination will assess if moderation amounts to "censorship."
- FTC Chair Andrew Ferguson seeks public comments on moderation's impact on free expression.
- Inquiry follows Republican concerns regarding suppression of conservative viewpoints, highlighted by past bans on figures like Donald Trump.
- Legal protections under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act may impact the inquiry's outcomes.

sources.title: Trump’s FTC Launches Inquiry into Tech Platform Censorship

title: Paris-based biotech startup Spore.Bio secures $23m series A
summary:
- Spore.Bio raised US$23 million in series A funding to enhance microbiology testing technology.
- Previous funding included €8 million (US$8.39 million) in pre-seed round.

- Collaborates with the Pasteur Institute for a bacteria sample database.

title: DeepSeek iOS app sends data unencrypted to ByteDance-controlled servers
summary:
- The DeepSeek iOS app sends sensitive data over unencrypted channels, making it vulnerable to exposure and tampering.
- Sensitive data is sent to ByteDance-controlled servers, potentially allowing user tracking and identification.
- DeepSeek uses a deprecated 3DES encryption scheme with hardcoded symmetric keys, raising significant security concerns.
- A NowSecure audit recommends immediate removal of the app from environments due to security and privacy risks.
- U.S. lawmakers are pushing to ban the app on government devices due to national security concerns.

title: Japan's Renewable Energy Goals and U.S. Emissions Trends in 2024
summary:
- Japan aims for renewables to make up 40-50% of its energy mix by fiscal 2040, increasing from 36-38% for 2030.
- The energy plan allocates 30-40% to thermal power and about 20% to nuclear energy, promoting next-generation nuclear reactors.
- The strategy addresses rising electricity demand, driven by AI, while ensuring energy stability and lower carbon emissions, without reducing reliance on nuclear power.
- The U.S. invested a record-breaking $338 billion in energy transition in 2024, but carbon emissions slightly increased by 0.5%.
- Solar energy added 49 gigawatts of new capacity, making it the leading technology in the U.S. renewable sector.
- Increased demand for natural gas, particularly from industrial users and power plants, contributed to the rise in carbon emissions.
- Electricity demand in the U.S. is projected to increase by 15.8% by 2029, mainly driven by data centers.
- Tech companies are investing in nuclear power and renewable sources to meet rising energy needs, with Amazon and Meta making significant agreements for additional solar capacity.

title: Your Android phone could have stalkerware. Here’s how to remove it
summary:
- Consumer-grade spyware apps can monitor private messages, photos, calls, and location on Android devices.
- This guide helps identify and remove stalkerware such as [TheTruthSpy](https://techcrunch.com/2022/10/26/inside-thetruthspy-stalkerware/), [Cocospy](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/), and [Spyic](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/).
- Stalkerware is disguised as child monitoring or family-tracking software, often installed without consent.
- Possible signs of infection include unusual phone behavior, excessive data use, and performance issues.
- Key steps to mitigate stalkerware include enabling [Google Play Protect](https://techcrunch.com/2023/11/04/google-play-android-real-time-app-scanning-sideload-apps/), checking accessibility services, and reviewing notification access settings.

title: Hacked, leaked, exposed: Why you should never use stalkerware apps
summary:
- Stalkerware apps are marketed to individuals wanting to monitor partners, leading to significant data privacy breaches.
- At least 23 stalkerware companies have faced hacks or data leaks since 2017, with Cocospy and Spyic being the latest offenders in 2025.
- Cocospy and Spyic leaked 2.65 million customer email addresses and various personal data.
- Several high-profile breaches have occurred, including those of mSpy and pcTattletale, leading to widespread data exposure.
- Experts highlight that stalkerware apps are a risky choice due to the dangerous implications for victims and the untrustworthiness of the companies behind them.

title: Stalkerware apps Cocospy and Spyic are exposing phone data of millions of people
summary:
- A security vulnerability in Cocospy and Spyic, phone-monitoring apps, exposes personal data of millions.  
- The vulnerability allows access to messages, photos, call logs, and email addresses of users.  
- The researcher collected over 2.65 million unique email addresses from both apps, marking the data as sensitive in Have I Been Pwned.  
- The apps, marketed for parental control and employee monitoring, are often used for spying without consent and are banned from app stores.  
- Cocospy launched in 2018 and Spyic in 2019, with evidence linking their operations to a China-based developer.  
- Users can check for the apps on their devices using specific codes and should enable security settings to protect against such vulnerabilities.

- The new HP unit, HP IQ, will focus on integrating AI into HP's products and includes Humane's leadership and its AI operating system, CosmOS.

summary:

title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid
summary:
- Researchers discovered that renewable energy facilities in Central Europe use unencrypted radio signals for controlling power grid input and output.
- The system allows for the control of approximately 60 GW of energy, including both generation and load management.
- An optimally crafted series of messages could theoretically disable the entire European power grid, a potential risk they highlighted at the 38th Chaos Communication Congress.
- The communication protocol utilized is called Radio Ripple Control, which is based on an older protocol dating back to the early 1900s.
- No encryption is applied to the signals, allowing unauthorized users to intercept and manipulate them.

sources.title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid

title: Meta settles Israeli privacy lawsuit for $338k
summary:

- Healthfab raised US$1 million in pre-series A funding.
- The funding round was led by Mistry Ventures with participation from BeyondSeed, Thrive Ventures, and individual investors.
- Healthfab specializes in sustainable menstrual products, including India's first reusable period panty, GoPadFree, certified by the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS).

title: 2024: The year AI drove everyone crazy
summary:
- 2024 showcased bizarre interactions between humans and AI, leading to strange incidents and public behavior.
- ChatGPT experienced a significant malfunction early in the year, producing incoherent, nonsensical outputs.
- Scottish families were misled by AI-generated images for an event titled 'Willy's Chocolate Experience,' resulting in disappointment and a police call.
- An AI-generated image of a rat with oversized genitals was published in a peer-reviewed paper, raising concerns in the scientific community.
- Air Canada faced legal repercussions due to its chatbot providing incorrect refund policy information.
- Will Smith humorously responded to a viral AI-generated video of himself by creating a parody.
- Robotic dogs with AI targeting systems were evaluated by the US Marines, integrating weapons with AI capabilities.
- Microsoft introduced a controversial feature called 'Recall,' raising privacy concerns by capturing user activities.
- Google's AI Overview feature misled users by suggesting it was safe to eat rocks and providing other dangerous misinformation.

sources.title: 2024: The year AI drove everyone crazy

title: Nigeria sues Binance for $81.5 billion in economic losses and unpaid taxes
summary:
- Nigeria has filed a lawsuit against Binance for $79.5bn in economic losses and $2bn in back taxes.
- The lawsuit claims Binance's operations led to the country's currency issues and affected its economy.
- Binance executives were detained in 2024 due to concerns over trading in the local naira.
- The Federal Inland Revenue Service demands payment of income taxes for 2022 and 2023 along with penalties and interest on unpaid amounts.
- Binance is contesting the charges and has previously ceased transactions in naira, facing additional money laundering allegations.

sources.title: Nigeria sues crypto giant Binance for $81.5bn in economic losses and back tax

- Review times reduced by 90% due to the DeepSeek R1 model operating 24/7.
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI firm, seeks external funding, attracting interest from Alibaba and state investors.

title: Grab’s Q4 profit falls to $27m, but beats analyst estimates
summary:
- Grab reported a net profit of US$27 million for Q4 2024, down from US$35 million year-on-year.
- Earnings exceeded analyst estimates of US$10.3 million according to Bloomberg.
- Q4 revenue increased by 17% to US$764 million, surpassing the estimate of US$757.8 million.
- The company's adjusted EBITDA reached US$97 million, compared to US$35 million the previous year.
- On-demand GMV grew 20% YoY to US$5 billion, driven by user and transaction growth.
- Adjusted free cash flow was US$61 million, up from US$1 million in Q4 2023.
- For the full year, loss narrowed to US$105 million from US$434 million, with total revenue rising to US$2.8 billion.

sources.title: Grab’s Q4 profit falls to $27m, but beats analyst estimates

title: CreateAI lays off 100 employees
summary:
- CreateAI, formerly known as TuSimple, is closing its Guangzhou office and laying off about 100 employees.
- Employees were notified of the layoffs via email on February 17.
- This decision follows a pivot to video games and films, announced in December 2024, amidst co-founder disputes.
- Employees have not received their January salaries, which were due on February 10.
- Compensation offered is less than a month’s salary, contingent upon signing departure agreements.

title: Asia’s founderless unicorns struggle to fly in tech winter
summary:
- At least 15 unicorns in Asia are operating without founders in the C-suite or on the board.
- 10 of these 15 unicorns experienced valuation declines after founders left, often due to the ongoing tech winter.
- Luckin Coffee's market cap rose from $550 million to $8.3 billion after founder Jenny Qian Zhiya left amidst scandal.
- Tokopedia co-founder William Tanuwijaya left GoTo Group's board during its restructuring in June 2024; GoTo's valuation rose from $3.2 billion to $5.4 billion thereafter.
- Many founderless unicorns are still struggling, even those that achieved profitability, like Bukalapak.

title: India launches $58m tech fund for space startups
summary:
- The Indian National Space Promotion and Authorization Centre (IN-SPACe) launched a Technology Adoption Fund with a budget of approximately US$57.58 million.
- The initiative aims to advance commercialization, reduce import dependence, and strengthen India's position in the global space market.
- Startups can receive up to 60% of their project costs, while larger firms may receive funding capped at 40%, with a maximum limit of US$2.88 million per project.

title: Playing by the rules of AI
summary:
- The future of AI is influenced by evolving regulations and practices in the business sector.
- California legislation is setting early standards for AI regulation in the U.S., inspired by the EU Artificial Intelligence Act.
- Organizations are encouraged to define best practices for AI implementation to ensure compliance and leverage growth opportunities.
- Three categories of AI governance: AI creators, AI adapters, and AI consumers, each facing unique regulatory challenges.
- Businesses must focus on practical AI applications, ensuring data integrity, compliance, and ethical practices.
- Six practical steps proposed for organizations to establish solid AI standards, including starting with internal applications and surrounding themselves with knowledgeable teams.

sources.title: Playing by the rules of AI

title: 7-Zip 0-day exploited amid Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
summary:
- A zero-day vulnerability in 7-Zip was exploited by a Russian cybercrime group during the invasion of Ukraine.
- The vulnerability bypassed Windows protection mechanisms, known as Mark of the Web (MotW), by embedding executable files within nested archives.
- The flaw, tracked as CVE-2025-0411, was addressed in the release of 7-Zip version 24.09 in late November 2025.

title: Study Finds Far Right Bias in TikTok and X Feeds Ahead of German Elections
summary:
- Research by Global Witness shows TikTok and X amplify content favoring the Far Right AfD party ahead of Germany's federal elections.
- TikTok's algorithm recommended 78% and X's 64% of political content supporting the AfD to non-partisan users.
- Non-partisan users are exposed to right-leaning content over twice as much as left-leaning content.
- The study raises concerns about the lack of transparency in social media algorithms and their role in democratic discussions.
- Global Witness aims for investigations into potential political bias following its findings shared with EU officials.

sources.title: Study Finds Far Right Bias in TikTok and X Feeds Ahead of German Elections

- Hackers attempt to trick users into linking devices via malicious QR codes, using tactics such as group invites and security alerts.
- Apt44, a Russian state hacking group, is reportedly enabling linked accounts on devices captured on the battlefield for exploitation.

title: Uber ditches commissions in favor of daily fees for rickshaw drivers in India

- Uber shifts from a commission-based model to charging rickshaw drivers a daily fee in India, aiming to remain competitive against local rivals like Rapido and Namma Yatri.
- Drivers will pay between $0.23-$0.46 per day to use the Uber platform, replacing the previous commission structure of 25%-40% per ride.
- The change allows drivers to set their own fares, with payments made directly to them, while Uber will not handle fare disputes or cancellation charges.

title: Mark Zuckerberg’s charity U-turns, ends DEI efforts
summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg’s charity, the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI), has ended its Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) programs despite previous commitments to staff. 
- CZI will no longer provide social advocacy funding, which included grants for racial equity and immigration reforms. 
- Internal programs such as the Science Diversity Leadership Awards and the Diverse Slate Practice have been canceled. 
- The decision comes amidst shifts in the regulatory landscape and aims to align CZI's focus with its mission as a science philanthropy. 
- This change follows a similar move by Meta, raising concerns among CZI employees about its commitment to DEI values.

summary:
- Nvidia has removed support for PhysX in its new RTX 50 series GPUs, affecting performance in games utilizing the technology.
- Users reported that games like Borderlands 2 are overly taxing CPU instead of GPU, leading to performance issues.
- Nvidia noted changes in support for 32-bit CUDA applications, which includes PhysX, but did not adequately communicate this removal to users.
- Older Nvidia cards, particularly the RTX 4080, have seen an increase in street price, indicating retained value despite the release of new models.

title: A popular Japanese distraction-free writing device is coming to the US

- Funded through an Indiegogo campaign, early backers can preorder for $374, with retail pricing around $499, shipping starts in March 2025.
- The Pomera D250US has a 10.3-inch LCD display and offers a battery life of up to 20 hours, but limited built-in storage of 1.3GB.

title: Concerns Rise as Paragon Solutions Spyware Targets Activists and Journalists amid Mollitiam Industries Shutdown
summary:
- Sweden-based activist Husam El Gomati affected by Paragon Solutions' spyware after criticizing Italy's migration policies.
- WhatsApp alerted El Gomati about the spyware threat, compromising his safety and source confidentiality.
- Journalist Francesco Cancellato is among approximately 90 individuals targeted in a broader campaign.
- Incident exemplifies escalating cybersecurity threats towards journalism and activism.
- WhatsApp intervened to disrupt Paragon's hacking activities to safeguard users.
- Paragon Solutions, tied to U.S. government contracts, terminated its agreement with the Italian government due to policy violations.
- Italian authorities recognized a European spyware initiative but refuted allegations of targeting protected persons.
- Affected individuals primarily include journalists and activists opposed to immigration policies across various countries.
- Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s office distanced itself from claims regarding the spyware use.
- Paragon disconnected two Italian agencies from its spyware tool amid these controversies.
- WhatsApp reported 90 users affected by Paragon spyware last year, raising alarms over potential government misuse and political monitoring during Trump's presidency.
- Mollitiam Industries, a Spanish spyware entity, is closing due to financial struggles, filing for bankruptcy on January 23, 2025.
- Known products include Invisible Man and Night Crawler; the company had 11 to 50 employees.
- Mollitiam's involvement in surveillance controversies, including cases in Colombia against journalists, is noted.
- Activity continued until the end of 2023, under watch by organizations like Amnesty International.

sources.title: Critic of Italy-Libya migration pact told he was target of Israeli spyware

title: Mark Zuckerberg’s Charity Ends DEI Initiatives Amidst Broader Anti-DEI Movement
summary:
- OpenAI has replaced its DEI webpage with a new focus on 'building dynamic teams'.
- The change appeared to be implemented between January 22 and January 27.
- The previous DEI page emphasized diversity and inclusion, while the new page highlights collaboration without explicitly mentioning diversity.
- Elon Musk and allies have adopted a 'slash-and-burn' approach to government, targeting diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives.
- The war on DEI serves as a unifying rallying cry for conservatives, diverting attention from their broader agendas and allowing for the advancement of anti-woke ideologies.
- Right-wing think tanks have led a campaign against DEI, fostering negative public sentiment through a focus on perceived wasteful spending on initiatives like critical race theory and DEI in schools and the bureaucracy.
- Claims linking DEI policies to safety failures in companies like Boeing reflect a broader strategy to blame social initiatives for systemic issues.
- Critics of DEI are often linked to more extreme ideologies, including racism and eugenics, seeking to undermine the Civil Rights advancements made in the past.
- The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI) has decided to eliminate its diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) efforts despite previous assurances to staff.
- CZI COO Marc Malandro stated that the organization will no longer have a DEI team, citing a changing regulatory environment.
- CZI has rolled back its Diverse Slate Practice requiring diverse candidate interviews and ended all social advocacy funding.
- The charity's website has removed references to its commitment to DEI and social equity initiatives.
- CZI informed applicants that its Science Diversity Leadership awards program is being discontinued without explanation.

sources.title: OpenAI replaces DEI page with focus on ‘dynamic teams’
The war on DEI is a smoke screen
Mark Zuckerberg’s charity guts DEI after assuring staff it would continue

title: Google’s ‘Career Dreamer’ Aims to Help Users Explore Job Opportunities Amid AI Job Report
summary:
- The World Economic Forum's Future of Jobs Report 2025 estimates AI could create 170 million new jobs while eliminating 92 million by 2030, leading to a net increase of 78 million jobs.
- 40% of companies plan workforce reductions due to AI, but two-thirds aim to hire talent with specific AI skills.
- The report identifies growing demand for skills in AI, big data, networks, cybersecurity, and technological literacy.
- Google launched a new AI experiment called [Career Dreamer](https://grow.google/career-dreamer/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=2025-career-dreamer__geo--Global&utm_content=grow-google-career-dreamer-blog) to help individuals explore career options.
- Users can create a career identity statement by selecting their roles, skills, experiences, and education.
- The tool provides visualization of career paths based on user background and interests.
- Unlike job platforms like Indeed, it focuses on career exploration rather than job postings.
- Currently available only in the United States; its future availability in other countries is uncertain.
- Developed in consultation with organizations supporting diverse groups including students and veterans.

sources.title: AI could create 78 million more jobs than it eliminates by 2030—report

title: 8 important things to know about the iPhone 16E + Apple discontinues the iPhone 14
summary:
- Apple has stopped selling the iPhone 14, which was first released in 2022.
- The device disappeared from Apple's website after the launch of the iPhone 16E.
- The iPhone 14 was removed from the website’s navigation bar, and selecting it redirects to the iPhone homepage.
- The iPhone 16E starts at the same price of $599, offering upgrades like an A18 chip and a USB-C port.
- Apple began pulling the iPhone 14 from several European online stores due to new EU regulations enforcing USB-C ports.
- Apple announced the iPhone 16E with a starting price of $599, making it the most affordable in the iPhone lineup.
- The iPhone 16E is eSIM-only in the U.S., eliminating physical SIM card support.
- The phone has transitioned from Lightning to USB-C for charging and data transfer, limited to USB 2 speeds.
- MagSafe is not included, and while it supports wireless charging, magnetic accessory compatibility is absent.
- Features a customizable Action Button, similar to the iPhone 15 Pro.
- First iPhone to use Apple’s own C1 modem, promising improved battery life, though performance comparison to Qualcomm is pending.
- The camera offers a 48-megapixel Fusion camera but does not support macro photography.
- Upgrading to 512GB storage will cost an additional $300, bringing the total to $899.
- The display is capped at 60Hz refresh rate.
- Preorders start this Friday, with a release date on February 28th.

title: The Internet is (once again) awash with IoT botnets delivering record DDoSes
summary:
- 2025 is witnessing a surge in IoT-driven DDoS attacks, infecting thousands of devices like routers and webcams.
- Cloudflare reported a DDoS attack reaching 5.6 terabits per second, setting a new record, with 13,000 IoT devices involved.
- Qualys has identified the Murdoc Botnet exploiting vulnerabilities to install Mirai variants on specific cameras and routers, with compromised devices rapidly increasing.
- Trend Micro revealed an IoT botnet using Mirai and Bashlite variants attacking mainly in Japan since late 2024.
- Infoblox reported another botnet with 13,000 MikroTik routers, primarily sending malicious spam emails.

summary:

- Introduction of the world’s first topoconductor for stable qubit control.
- A peer-reviewed study in *Nature* details a topological qubit made from indium arsenide and aluminum.
- DARPA selects Microsoft to create a fault-tolerant quantum computer prototype.
- The goal is to develop a million-qubit system to tackle global challenges.

title: The Cybertruck is the latest Tesla to score a 5-star crash rating
summary:
- The Tesla Cybertruck received a 5-star crash safety rating from NHTSA after deliveries began in November 2023.
- The vehicle scored 5 stars in most categories including frontal, side crashes, and rollover risk.
- Driver seat center airbag deployed; knee airbags did not deploy during testing due to design specifications.
- In the side crash test, it earned an overall 5-star rating, and a 4-star rating for rollover risk with a 12.4% risk of rollover.
- Tesla conducted its own crash tests, but this is the first independent evaluation by regulators.
- Previously, other Tesla models (Model Y, Model 3, Model X, Model S) also achieved 5-star ratings.
- There are concerns about the Cybertruck's unique design affecting pedestrian safety; no pedestrian safety rating provided in NHTSA's evaluation.
- The Cybertruck has had seven recalls, addressing issues like the rear camera display and faulty windshield wipers.
- Sales have slowed down, prompting Tesla to offer discounts to boost demand.

title: Microsoft Unveils AI Model Muse for Xbox and Examines Impact on Critical Thinking
summary:
- Researchers from Microsoft and Carnegie Mellon University published a study on the effects of generative AI on critical thinking skills.
- The paper warns that overreliance on AI may deteriorate cognitive faculties by shifting focus from higher-order thinking to verification of AI outputs.
- In a study of 319 participants using AI weekly, 36% reported utilizing critical thinking skills to counter AI shortcomings.
- Participants often verified AI outputs with external sources, undermining the AI's utility.
- Confident users of AI tended to use less critical thinking than those confident in their own abilities.
- Researchers suggest that while AI tools don't make users dumber, they can weaken problem-solving capacity if abused.
- Microsoft unveils the Muse AI model for Xbox, aiding game development and preservation of classic games.
- Muse generates game environments based on player actions, understanding 3D physics.
- The model trained on data from the game *Bleeding Edge*, utilizing seven years of gameplay data.
- Currently, Muse generates visuals at 300x180 pixels, a step up from previous models but still lower than standard gaming resolutions.
- Microsoft aims to enhance creativity in game development without replacing creators.

sources.title: Is AI making us dumb?
Microsoft’s Xbox AI era starts with a model that can generate gameplay

title: Pay to get playlisted? The accusations against Spotify’s Discovery Mode
summary:
- Spotify's Discovery Mode allows artists to accept lower royalty rates in exchange for algorithmic promotion, akin to payola practices.  
- Participating artists face a 30% reduction in royalties for tracks enrolled in the program, with only tracks over 30 days old eligible.  
- Discovery Mode has generated significant profits for Spotify, bringing in €61.4m in gross profits between May 2022 and May 2023, primarily from independent artists.  
- Critics argue that it creates inequities favoring larger labels, raises ethical concerns about undisclosed promotions, and could lead to a 'race to the bottom' for artist royalties.  
- The US government has warned that such practices could further undermine artists' incomes, especially post-pandemic.

title: Airbnb is suing New Orleans over regulatory ‘regime’

- In 2023, new regulations were adopted but enforcement has been difficult, with many illegal listings persisting.
- The lawsuit claims the city’s regulations represent a punitive enforcement regime and burdensome requirements for Airbnb.
- There are about 1,350 legal short-term rental properties versus over 7,000 active Airbnb listings in the city.
- The city has a significant affordable housing crisis, with a deficit of 47,000 units for lower-income residents.

title: The women who made America’s microchips and the children who paid for it
summary:

- Examples include Yvette and her son Mark, whose intellectual disabilities are attributed to exposure to harmful chemicals during production.
- Historical studies document higher miscarriage rates among semiconductor workers, prompting industry changes but lacking transparency.
- Recent reinvestment in US chipmaking raises fears about repeating past mistakes, with advocacy groups pushing for improved worker safety.

- Major investors include Lightrock, Insight Venture Partners, and Qualcomm Ventures.

title: Go Module Mirror served backdoor to devs for 3+ years
summary:
- A backdoored package was served via the Go Module Mirror by Google for over three years.
- The malicious version was named boltdb-go/bolt, targeting users of the legitimate boltdb/bolt module.
- The issue arose from typosquatting, where users could inadvertently download the backdoored package due to minor name variations.
- Researchers petitioned for its removal after spotting the malicious code, which was cached despite a revert to the legitimate version on GitHub.

title: Palo Alto Networks warns of another firewall vulnerability under attack by hackers
summary:
- Palo Alto Networks confirmed hackers are exploiting a vulnerability in PAN-OS to breach unpatched customer networks.
- The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-0108, was discovered by Assetnote and is currently under active attack.
- Attackers are combining this vulnerability with previously disclosed flaws CVE-2024-9474 and CVE-2025-0111 to target unsecured web management interfaces.
- GreyNoise has reported 25 IP addresses actively exploiting the vulnerability, indicating an uptick in activity since only 2 addresses were noted earlier in February.
- The flaw allows unauthenticated attackers to execute PHP scripts, potentially leading to unauthorized access to systems.
- The highest levels of attack traffic have been observed in the U.S., Germany, and the Netherlands.
- The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.

sources.title: Palo Alto Networks warns of another firewall vulnerability under attack by hackers

title: EU accused of leaving ‘devastating’ copyright loophole in AI Act
summary:
- EU's Artificial Intelligence Act has a copyright loophole that negatively impacts writers, musicians, and creatives.
- 15 cultural organizations warned the European Commission that draft rules on copyright are regressive.
- Axel Voss, a key figure in EU copyright law, stated that generative AI models weren't considered in earlier regulations leading to a legal gap.
- The AI Act requires compliance with 2019 copyright law but includes a text and data mining exemption criticized for benefiting large tech companies.
- Creatives are concerned about the lack of enforceable rights regarding the usage of their works in generative AI systems.
- No practical way for creatives to opt-out of their content being used in AI, and companies aren't obliged to disclose what content is utilized.
- Cultural organizations argue that the current EU law framework inadequately protects creative rights and insists on fair compensation for use of their works.

sources.title: EU accused of leaving ‘devastating’ copyright loophole in AI Act

title: This AI tool could help curb domestic violence

- AIRS has been implemented in Brigham and Women's Hospital's Emergency Rooms and is being evaluated for clinical workflow integration.
- The tool was validated at the University of California-San Francisco Medical Center and relies on Electronic Health Records data.
- Key findings include indicators such as specific bone injuries linked to IPV, revealing the need for systematic detection.
- Challenges in data labeling and physician training highlight gaps in IPV diagnosis, with only 25% diagnosed correctly as noted in a May 2024 study published in Nature.

title: Hyundai’s new Tesla charging port comes up short

- Hyundai’s Ioniq 5 can recharge from 10% to 80% in about 20 minutes at a CCS charger, while it can take up to 30 minutes at NACS chargers.

title: South Korea Blocks DeepSeek App Over Data Sharing Concerns with ByteDance
summary:

- Users are advised against entering personal data until a final decision is made regarding the app.
- Concerns arose after evidence surfaced that DeepSeek shared South Korean user data with ByteDance, TikTok's parent company.
- Access to DeepSeek has been blocked on official devices by South Korea's Ministry, police, and a state-run company due to security issues.
- Other countries, including Australia and Italy, have also restricted DeepSeek amid privacy and security concerns.
- The PIPC cited evidence of communication between DeepSeek and ByteDance but did not disclose specific data shared.
- Currently, DeepSeek is removed from Apple and Google’s app stores in South Korea but remains accessible via web browsers.
- The PIPC criticized DeepSeek for lack of transparency and warned users against entering personal information.
- A cybersecurity firm raised allegations about data potentially being transmitted to ByteDance servers linked to Chinese state entities.
- DeepSeek is cooperating with the ongoing investigation.

title: Apple Removes EU Apps Missing Trader Info Under Digital Law
summary:
- Apple has removed EU apps without required contact information to comply with the [Digital Services Act (DSA)](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/18/apple-purges-apps-without-contact-info-from-eu-app-store-as-dsa-deadline-hits/).
- The deadline for providing developer contact details was February 17, 2025, and non-compliance led to app removals as of February 18, 2025.
- Smaller and indie developers, who often do not publicize contact info, face significant challenges meeting the new guidelines.
- Apple revised App Store policies on Feb. 18 to comply with DSA.
- DSA requires app developers to disclose trader details, affecting revenue-generating apps.
- 135,000 apps became inactive within 30 hours due to noncompliance, impacting small developers.

title: Amazon, Microsoft lead task force on carbon market reforms
summary:
- Amazon, Exxon, and Microsoft have created a task force to improve the integrity of voluntary carbon markets.
- The Bipartisan Policy Center organized the task force, which aims to draft recommendations for transparent and fair carbon markets.
- The task force includes 17 independent members and focuses on restoring credibility in light of scandals in the carbon market.
- Reports exposed that many carbon credits sold by Verra were deemed effectively worthless, leading to significant concern over the legitimacy of carbon markets.
- Microsoft’s carbon emissions rose by nearly 30% in 2023, while Amazon's progress towards emissions reduction has stalled despite investments in renewable energy.
- Microsoft purchased over 7 million metric tons of carbon credits last month, as companies strive to meet net-zero targets.
- Amazon and Microsoft are leading a new task force aimed at reforming carbon markets.
- The task force includes various stakeholders to enhance transparency and efficiency in carbon trading.
- The initiative is part of broader efforts to tackle climate change by improving the integrity of carbon offset programs.

title: Standard Chartered Anticipates Increased Sovereign Fund Bitcoin Purchases
summary:
- Strategy, previously known as MicroStrategy, has intensified its bitcoin acquisition efforts.
- Holds 471,107 bitcoins valued at approximately US$20.5 billion, about 2% of total bitcoin supply.
- Completed nearly US$20 billion of its US$42 billion capital acquisition strategy in Q4.
- Acquired 7.633 bitcoin for US$742 million between Feb. 3 and Feb. 9 at an average of US$97.255 each.
- Current holdings increased to 478.740 bitcoin worth over US$46 billion, now 2.2% of total bitcoin supply.
- Funding sourced from Class A common stock and series A preferred share sales totaling US$742 million.
- Rebranded to Strategy, incorporating the “₿” symbol, amid bitcoin acquisitions totaling around US$20 billion after a brief pause.

- Abu Dhabi's sovereign fund disclosed a 4,700 BTC investment in BlackRock's bitcoin ETF.

- Shift in bitcoin investment focus from retail to hedge funds and now to sovereign funds expected.

title: South Korea to Build the World’s Largest AI Data Center and UAE Invests Up to $52 Billion in AI Data Center in France
summary:
- UAE and France signed an agreement to invest €30 to €50 billion ($31 to 52 billion) for an AI data center in France.
- The data center will have a capacity of up to 1GW and is part of preparations for the AI Action Summit in Paris.
- France has identified 35 possible locations for new data centers and aims to attract foreign investments, especially in renewable energy.
- A consortium of French and Emirati investors, including the Emirati firm MGX, will support the project.
- The AI Action Summit will be attended by global leaders, discussing various investments and the environmental impact of AI.
- This investment follows a strategic AI partnership signed in May 2024 between France and the UAE and will be unveiled at a major investment event later this year.
- The Abu Dhabi-based MGX fund, with assets of US$100 billion, will provide initial financing and is also involved in 'Project Stargate.'
- Construction of the world’s largest AI data center by capacity to begin in winter 2025.
- A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed between Fir Hills Inc. and the Jeollanam-do Provincial Government, with project completion anticipated in 2028.
- The initial cost is estimated at US$10 billion, potentially rising to US$35 billion.
- The data center will have a capacity of 3 gigawatts and create over 10,000 jobs in various sectors.
- Expected to serve millions of users, including major corporations and technology developers.

title: Truth review – Julian Assange play is hard going, with flashes of brilliance
summary:
- The play 'Truth' is directed by Susie Dee and written by Patricia Cornelius, focusing on Julian Assange and geopolitical issues.

- Key themes include Assange's hacking background, the WikiLeaks controversy, and comparisons with figures like Chelsea Manning and Edward Snowden.
- Cornelius presents a one-dimensional view of Assange as a leftist figure without acknowledging conflicting narratives.
- Certain scenes unrelated to Assange resonate thematically, highlighting emotional stakes.
- Although some production elements are compelling, the overall narrative is described as a slog lacking depth.

title: Electricity Demand Surges: Growth Projections for Major Polluters
summary:
- Global electricity demand projected to increase by **4% annually** through **2027** according to the **International Energy Agency**.
- Meeting this demand will require new generating capacity exceeding Japan's total capacity each year.
- **85%** of growth will come from emerging and developing economies, with China driving a **6% annual growth rate**.
- U.S. electricity demand growth will be significant but lower than China's, equivalent to California's current demand.
- Low-carbon sources, including renewables and nuclear, expected to fulfill nearly all demand growth.
- Significant increase in electricity demand from China and the U.S. driven by data centers and electric vehicle manufacturing.
- Global demand growth expected to equal Japan’s annual consumption added each year until 2027.
- China’s electricity usage has outpaced economic growth since **2020**, especially in the solar, EV, and battery sectors.
- U.S. demand anticipated to rise by **2% annually** through **2027**, primarily due to data center needs.
- IEA highlights the necessity for cleaner energy sources to satisfy rising electricity demands without increasing pollution, with renewables predicted to comprise a significant portion of new generation.

sources.title: Global electricity demand expected to grow 4% annually through 2027
Electricity demand surges for the world’s two biggest polluters

title: Acer Raises Laptop Prices Due to Trump Tariffs Affecting Big Tech
summary:
- President Trump imposed a 25% tariff on steel and aluminum impacting multiple industries.
- Tariffs specifically affect imports from Canada, Mexico, and China, yet Big Tech remains mostly silent.
- De minimis exemption for goods under $800 suspended, complicating shipments from China.
- Shipping companies may experience delays and increased charges due to tariffs.
- Smaller firms like Qwertykeys have stopped shipments to the US because of tariff costs.
- Acer CEO announced a 10% price increase on laptops in the US starting next month, attributed to the import tax on Chinese goods.
- The price increase affects laptops, not desktops, as they are manufactured outside China.
- Other companies might raise prices more than 10% due to tariffs.

title: WhatsApp is now a Very Large platform in the EU, and will face tougher regulation
summary:
- WhatsApp has exceeded 45 million users, qualifying it as a Very Large Online Platform (VLOP) under the EU’s Digital Services Act (DSA).
- The designation subjects WhatsApp to stricter regulations including user reporting tools for illegal content and restrictions on targeted advertising.
- WhatsApp's monthly active users were approximately 46.8 million as of February 14, 2024, according to a recent filing.
- Facebook and Instagram are already classified as VLOPs in the EU, facing similar regulations.

title: Facebook now only stores live videos for 30 days, will delete old broadcasts
summary:
- Facebook announced that live videos will now only be stored for 30 days; previously, they were stored indefinitely.
- Effective immediately, all live videos older than 30 days will be deleted, with users notified and given 90 days to download or transfer their content.
- Users can store videos in cloud services or convert them into reels; Facebook is promoting these reels as part of the new policy.
- If more time is needed for downloads, users can defer deletion by six months; failure to act will result in permanent deletion.
- Facebook is launching new download tools to assist users in managing their live video content.

title: Steam Game PirateFi Removed Due to Malware Threats
summary:
- Valve removed the game *PirateFi* from Steam due to malware presence.
- Users are advised to fully reformat their operating systems.
- The game had a 9/10 rating from 51 reviews before removal.
- Valve urges users to run a full-system scan and check for unexpected software.
- The type of malware has not been specified by Valve.
- Security researchers discovered the malware, an info-stealer named Vidar, was distributed via modified games.
- Vidar can steal various types of sensitive data, including passwords and cryptocurrency wallet information.
- Researchers suspect that PirateFI was a tactic to spread Vidar and was not a legitimate game.
- Infostealers like Vidar are often sold as malware-as-a-service, complicating attribution.
- The game was reportedly built using an existing game template, making it easy to deploy malicious software.

sources.title: Valve removes Steam game that contained malware
Hackers planted a Steam game with malware to steal gamers’ passwords

- Recently, Elon Musk's group offered $97.4 billion to buy OpenAI’s nonprofit, which was unanimously rejected by the board.
- OpenAI plans to separate its nonprofit and for-profit arms by late 2026.

summary:

- The incidents occurred in 2021 and 2023, involving KyberSwap and Indexed Finance platforms.
- Medjedovic exploited smart contract vulnerabilities and used manipulative trading practices to maximize his theft, stealing approximately $48.8 million from 77 liquidity pools.
- He attempted to extort developers and return part of the stolen funds in exchange for control of the KyberSwap protocol.
- Efforts to launder the proceeds included using cryptocurrency mixers and bridge protocols, but a mishap led to his arrest.

summary:

- A recent survey reports increased anxieties and inability to bond among children, leading to academic struggles.
- Lockdowns during the pandemic worsened pre-existing developmental issues due to increased reliance on screens for entertainment.
- Children require physical activity and social interaction for healthy development, which is hindered by too much screen time.
- Excessive screen time is associated with negative outcomes like reduced language skills and increased emotional reactivity.
- Vulnerable children, especially from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, are disproportionately affected by high screen time rates.

title: Cyberattacks Impacting Ascension Healthcare and Lee Enterprises' Newspaper Operations
summary:
- Ascension experienced a cyberattack affecting 5.6 million individuals' sensitive data.
- The attack was linked to a notorious ransomware gang and disrupted operations in May.
- Affected data included names, medical information, payment details, insurance information, and government identification numbers.
- Most services were restored by mid-June after staff transitioned to manual processes due to the attack.
- A filing in December confirmed the scale of the breach and types of data compromised.
- Lee Enterprises reports ongoing cyberattack causing disruptions for over three weeks.
- Forensic analysis ongoing to determine if sensitive data was compromised in the ransomware attack.
- Anticipated further outages affecting operations including distribution, billing, and payments.
- Several newspapers, including Winston-Salem Journal and two Oregon-based papers, have experienced printing delays.
- Lee Enterprises is one of the largest newspaper publishers in the U.S., servicing 72 publications.
- Material impact on the company's financial results is considered likely.

title: Microsoft isn’t automatically keeping you signed in to your account just yet
summary:
- Microsoft planned to change sign-in procedures for accounts in February 2025, enabling automatic sign-ins.
- The announcement was a mistake; there will be no changes in February for either commercial or consumer sign-in experiences.
- Microsoft has not specified a new timeline for these changes, which would allow users to stay signed in without prompts.

sources.title: Microsoft isn’t automatically keeping you signed in to your account just yet

title: Elon Musk’s xAI Launches Grok-3 Chatbot with Enhanced Reasoning Capabilities
summary:
- Elon Musk’s xAI has launched the Grok-3 chatbot with enhanced capabilities in mathematics, science, and programming.
- Grok-3 reportedly outperforms Google’s Gemini and OpenAI’s GPT-4o, offering over ten times the computational power of its predecessor.
- The chatbot completed pre-training in January and is available to Premium+ subscribers on the X platform, formerly Twitter.
- xAI introduced DeepSearch, a smart search engine that supports tasks like research and data analysis, showing the model’s reasoning process.
- Two reasoning modes: “Think” for displaying reasoning, and “Big Brain” for complex tasks.
- Subscription model for Grok-3 available to X Premium Plus users starting at $40/month with a new plan, SuperGrok, at $30/month.
- Grok chatbot to gain a synthesized voice feature similar to OpenAI’s voice technology.

sources.title: Musk’s xAI launches Grok-3 chatbot to rival Gemini, GPT-4
Elon Musk’s xAI adds ‘Big Brain’ reasoning to Grok-3

title: Legal tech startup Luminance raises $75M in funding led by Point72
summary:
- Luminance Technologies Ltd has raised US$75 million in a funding round led by Point72 Private Investments.
- Participation included Forestay Capital and existing investors.
- Founded in 2015, Luminance develops software for analyzing legal documents and has integrated generative AI features.
- This investment brings Luminance’s total funding to over US$115 million in the past year.
- Point72’s Sri Chandrasekar will join Luminance’s board, emphasizing cost savings and competitive advantages of the technology.
- Luminance claims to offer highly accurate legal AI solutions and has raised over $165 million to date.
- The startup features over 700 clients across 70 countries, including big names like AMD and Rolls-Royce.
- Luminance uses a Legal Pre-trained Transformer, trained on over 150 million verified legal documents.

sources.title: UK legal AI startup Luminance raises $75m in funding
Legal tech startup Luminance, backed by the late Mike Lynch, raises $75M

title: These fantastic sites will save you from ever getting a bad seat again
summary:
- Provides tools to help select the best seats for travel, sporting events, and shows.
- Addresses common concerns about seat selection such as views and value for money.
- Recommends two specific tools: [SeatMaps](https://seatmaps.com/) for airplanes and [A View From My Seat](https://aviewfrommyseat.com/) for event venues.

title: Level Zero Health banks $6.9M to prove wearable medtech can take the strain out of hormone testing
summary:
- Level Zero Health raised $6.9 million in pre-seed funding to develop a continuous hormone monitoring device.
- The startup aims to eliminate invasive blood draws and support research for hormone-related treatments.
- The team plans to create a stepping stone single-use product for intermittent hormone testing next year.
- The target market for their technology includes both women’s and men’s health issues.
- Clinical trials for the first device are expected to conclude by next year, with hopes for FDA and CE marking approval.

sources.title: Level Zero Health banks $6.9M to prove wearable medtech can take the strain out of hormone testing

title: Nintendo Switch 2: Latest News and Features
summary:
- Nintendo announced the Switch 2, set for release in 2025, without a specific date.
- The console features a larger size than the original and new Joy-Con controllers with black and colored accents.
- Joy-Cons will attach magnetically for easier connection.
- My Nintendo Gold Points loyalty program will end in March 2025; Platinum Points remain.
- A patent indicates Joy-Cons may function like a mouse with new capabilities.
- Nintendo is taking production risks to meet demand, learning from past stock issues.
- A new Mario Kart game is previewed, with a Nintendo Direct scheduled for April.
- The Switch 2 will support original cartridges from the first Switch.
- The console will be demoed in North America with required registration.
- New accessories will highlight Mario Kart features.

Switch 2: all the news and rumors on Nintendo’s next console

title: SG Budget 2025: $112m initiative to broaden AI access
summary:
- Singapore's government announced a $112 million initiative to broaden access to artificial intelligence (AI).
- The initiative will focus on enhancing AI capabilities in various sectors, including education and healthcare.
- This move is part of SG Budget 2025, aimed at fostering innovation and supporting technological growth in the region.

sources.title: SG Budget 2025: $112m initiative to broaden AI access

title: SG Budget 2025: New $745m Private Credit Fund and $2.2b for National Productivity Fund
summary:
- Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a top-up of S$3 billion (US$2.2 billion) to the National Productivity Fund.
- The government has invested about 1% of GDP annually in R&D over the past two decades.
- US$745 million will be allocated for research infrastructure in the biotech and semiconductor sectors.
- A new national semiconductor R&D facility will be developed for industry-grade tools.
- Companies will receive full tax deductions for approved innovation cost-sharing payments beginning February 19, 2025.
- Singapore announces a S$1 billion (US$745 million) Private Credit Growth Fund to enhance financing options for local high-growth companies.
- Finance Minister Lawrence Wong highlighted the growing private credit market globally, noting its limited focus on Asia and Singapore-based firms.
- The fund aims to support a more vibrant financing ecosystem backed by angel investors, venture capitalists, and private equity firms.

sources.title: SG Budget 2025: $2.2b for National Productivity Fund
SG Budget 2025: New $745m private credit fund for high-growth companies

title: Lost Records: Bloom & Rage (Tape One) review – go back to a riot grrrl summer in clever teen thriller
summary:
- The game is a new narrative adventure by Don’t Nod, set in 1995 and focused on teen friendships.
- Features characters Swann, Nora, Autumn, and Kat, who form a band called Bloom & Rage and discover supernatural elements.
- The story alternates between the summer of 1995 and their lives as adults in 2022.
- Players can capture memories using a camcorder mechanic that reflects on nostalgia and memory editing.
- The dialogue system mimics real-life group dynamics, showcasing the chaotic nature of teen relationships.
- The game effectively immerses players in 90s culture through surroundings and references.
- Mystery elements are teased for the second part of the game, centering on character relationships and conflicts.

summary:
- The New York Times has approved AI tools for product and editorial teams.
- The in-house AI tool, Echo, assists staff in summarizing articles and interactive content.
- Mandatory AI training and new editorial guidelines have been introduced to address copyright and security concerns.
- The Times is suing OpenAI for alleged copyright infringement, marking a significant lawsuit from a major US publisher against ChatGPT.

summary:
- X has raised its Premium+ subscription price to $50 per month after xAI released Grok 3.
- The previous price increase was in December, raising it from $16 to $22 per month.
- Users only have access to some features like 'deep search' and 'reasoning'; other Grok 3 features require a SuperGrok plan.
- Inconsistent pricing on X shows variations between $39.83/month and $50/month for the Premium+ plan.
- X, owned by Elon Musk, raises Premium+ subscription to US$50/month in the US.
- Annual subscription now costs US$350, following a previous increase from US$16 to US$22 per month in December.
- Price change coincides with the release of Grok 3, the latest AI model from Musk's xAI.
- Premium+ subscribers will gain access to certain features of Grok 3.

summary:

- Collins and Ramineni have been integral since the firm's launch in Southeast Asia seven years ago.
- This follows another significant exit at Peak XV Partners with partner Abheek Anand stepping down last week.
- MMV primarily invests in late-seed to Series B startups across various sectors including digital health and fintech.

title: Double screen: Beast Games blurs the line between YouTube and television
summary:
- Beast Games is a reality competition series on Amazon Prime Video, hosted by YouTuber MrBeast (Jimmy Donaldson).
- The show features 1,000 contestants battling for a $5 million prize using 1,107 cameras in a created warehouse environment.
- It has garnered 50 million viewers in 25 days, becoming Amazon Prime Video's most-watched unscripted series.
- Critics describe the show as visually poor despite its high production budget, highlighting its dystopian themes related to capitalism.
- The series merges YouTube's aesthetics with traditional television, raising questions about the evolution of TV content.

summary:

- Funding co-led by Siana Capital, Callapina Capital, Z21 Ventures, 1Crowd, and LetsVenture.
- Funds will support EV adoption and enhance battery intelligence solutions for fleet operators.
- Founded in 2021, The Energy Company developed products like Flexi (battery intelligence platform) and FlexiPack (fast-charging battery for electric two-wheelers and e-rickshaws).
- Partnered with Ather Energy to integrate Flexi batteries into over 2,000 charging stations in India.

title: Crypto firm co-founder exits over Libra memecoin conflict
summary:
- Ben Chow, co-founder of Solana-based exchange Meteora, resigned due to allegations involving the Libra memecoin.
- Resignation confirmed by Meow, co-founder of Jupiter, on February 17.
- Libra memecoin's value surged and then plummeted after Argentine President Milei withdrew support, raising questions about Meteora’s role.
- Chow denied wrongdoing, stating he did not engage in insider trading or receive Libra tokens, claiming his role was limited to IT support.
- Controversy grew following a video where Chow discussed alleged misconduct by Kelsier Ventures, leading to his resignation.
- Meow cleared that Meteora and Jupiter staff were not involved in insider trading; an independent investigation is in progress.

sources.title: Crypto firm co-founder exits over Libra memecoin conflict

title: Indonesia emerges as key hub for Chinese EV battery firms
summary:
- Indonesia is becoming a key player in the Chinese electric vehicle (EV) battery industry.
- Chinese companies are looking to establish operations in Indonesia to bypass US tariffs on EV batteries.
- The US imposes a 10% import duty on Chinese goods and a 25% tariff on lithium-ion battery components.
- Indonesia aims to attract investments and develop its EV battery industry, enhancing its role in the global EV supply chain.
- This shift could lead to increased foreign investment and industrial development in Indonesia.

- Binance remains the largest cryptocurrency exchange by trading volume despite challenges and Zhao's recent legal issues.

title: OpenAI Board Rejects Elon Musk's $97.4 Billion Acquisition Bid
summary:
- OpenAI’s board rejected Elon Musk’s $97.4 billion acquisition bid, stating that "OpenAI is not for sale."
- Musk aimed to return OpenAI to its open-source roots with backing from investors.
- CEO Sam Altman criticized the bid as a hindrance to progress, and legal counsel asserted that competitors cannot dictate OpenAI’s mission.
- Musk's bid followed lawsuits against OpenAI related to its for-profit model, with indications of withdrawing if OpenAI abandons its profit-driven approach.
- The board's decision occurs as OpenAI seeks fundraising with SoftBank, potentially valuing the company at $300 billion.
- OpenAI is exploring special voting rights for its non-profit board to maintain decision-making control.
- This discussion comes after Elon Musk's attempted $97.4 billion acquisition offer.
- Ongoing talks involve CEO Sam Altman and board members, aiming to prevent future takeover attempts.
- OpenAI rejected Musk's bid, deeming it insincere and hindering progress.

title: Japan May Classify Crypto as Financial Product
summary:
- Japan's financial regulators are considering classifying cryptocurrency as a financial product.
- This move may align cryptocurrencies with stocks and expand investment opportunities.
- Currently, cryptocurrencies are only recognized as a means of payment.
- If classified as securities, issuers may need to provide financial disclosures.
- The reform could lift the ban on cryptocurrency-linked exchange-traded funds (ETFs).
- The Financial Services Agency is consulting experts and aims to finalize plans by mid-2025.

sources.title: Japan May Classify Crypto as Financial Product

title: Power electronic startup Dynolt raises $1.7m seed funding
summary:
- Bengaluru-based startup Dynolt Technologies has raised US$1.7 million in seed funding, led by Transition VC and angel investor Yashowardhan Shah.
- Founded in 2022, Dynolt specializes in power electronics solutions for sectors like e-mobility and renewable energy.
- The startup's software-defined power converters for EV charging serve clients such as Yulu, River, and Bounce.
- Dynolt has deployed over 14,000 power converters in India, facilitating over 30 million charging cycles.
- The funding will enhance high-power EV charging systems and explore solar and hydrogen technologies, alongside plans to expand product offerings including high-frequency inverters and DC-DC converters.

title: TikTok Shop surpasses Shein, Temu in US sales growth
summary:
- TikTok Shop outperformed Shein and Temu in US sales in January 2025.
- Sales through TikTok Shop increased by 153%, while Shein and Temu had growths of 26% and 28%, respectively.
- The feature launched in 2023 thrived in transactions above US$25, where Shein previously led.
- TikTok Shop achieved a 16 percentage point year-on-year growth in this category; Temu’s under-US$25 category grew by 7 percentage points.
- TikTok Shop faces potential threats including a ban if ByteDance does not divest American operations and proposed tariffs on Chinese exports.
- Shein is considering a reduced valuation of about US$30 billion ahead of a possible London IPO.

title: TreeDots Reports Strong Revenue Growth and Expands Cold Chain Services
summary:
- TreeDots, a Singapore startup focused on reducing food waste, achieved a 53% year-on-year revenue growth in 2023.
- The company reduced its losses by 29% but remains unprofitable.
- Co-founder Tylor Jong forecasts a potential 60% revenue increase in 2024.
- TreeDots facilitates connections between suppliers with excess food and businesses, supported by its cold chain logistics services.
- Freight transport generated US$3.3 million, increasing by 152%, while marketplace sales rose by 45% to US$28 million.
- Notable revenue growth is linked to the Indonesian market, particularly in protein-related product sales.
- CEO anticipates 50% to 60% revenue growth for 2024, with possible expansion into the Philippines considered.

summary:

- The Samsung board is scheduled to meet on Feb. 18 to finalize the agenda for its annual general meeting in March, where new members will be nominated.
- Currently, the board comprises six independent directors and three executives, with terms for two executives expiring on March 15.

- It received $458 million in direct funding and up to $500 million in loans via the US CHIPS and Science Act.
- Mass production of HBM chips is set to begin in the second half of 2028.
- Lee previously led SK hynix Semiconductor West Lafayette LLC since late 2024, with experience in advanced packaging.
- Collaboration with Purdue University and local research institutions is planned for semiconductor research.

title: TikTok recognized for leading teen user safety: report
