title: What the US’ first major AI copyright ruling might mean for IP law + Thomson Reuters wins first AI fair use copyright case
summary:
- A US judge ruled that Ross Intelligence cannot use Thomson Reuters content for its AI-based legal platform.
- This is the first fair use decision in an AI copyright case.
- Fair use is often cited by tech firms in AI training disputes, but copyright holders argue it harms their businesses.
- Thomson Reuters supported the ruling, asserting that Ross's use did not meet fair use criteria.
- A U.S. federal judge issued a summary judgment in a case against Ross Intelligence by Thomson Reuters regarding AI training material.
- The judge ruled Ross infringed on Reuters' intellectual property by using headnotes from Westlaw for its AI legal research tool.
- The judge deemed Ross' argument of transformative use unconvincing, as it did not add new meaning or purpose.
- The ruling may influence other pending AI copyright cases, although its narrow application is noted.
- The decision distinguishes between Ross' AI, which does not generate content, and generative AI, leading to further discussions on fair use in AI training data.

title: 161 years ago, a New Zealand sheep farmer predicted AI doom
summary:
- A New Zealand sheep farmer, Samuel Butler, predicted AI safety concerns such as machine consciousness and self-replication over 161 years ago.
- His writings influenced themes in later works like Asimov's and Frank Herbert's novels.
- Butler's 1872 novel, Erewhon, illustrated a society that banned machines invented within the last 300 years due to concerns about machine evolution.
- He emphasized the relationship between the evolution of machines and Darwinian principles, expressing admiration for Darwin's work.
- Despite being written in a time of rudimentary calculating devices, Butler's predictions about machine intelligence have proven to be remarkably insightful and relevant today.

title: US splits world into three tiers for AI chip access
summary:
- The US government announced new regulations on global AI chip exports, dividing the world into three tiers of access.
- The rules impose quotas for about 120 countries and allow unrestricted access for 18 close US allies while banning China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea.
- New regulations build on previous chip controls from September 2022 and October 2023, set to take effect in 120 days.
- First-tier countries face no restrictions, while second-tier countries can receive a limited number of advanced computing chips based on agreements with the US.
- Orders of up to 1,700 advanced chips do not require licenses, facilitating purchases by educational and medical institutions.

sources.title: US splits world into three tiers for AI chip access

title: Nvidia unveils $3,000 desktop AI computer for home researchers
summary:

- The computer features the GB10 Grace Blackwell Superchip, a combination of an Nvidia Blackwell GPU and a 20-core Grace CPU.
- Project DIGITS can run AI models with up to 200 billion parameters, and two linked units can handle models with 405 billion parameters, aiming to provide local AI capabilities.

title: Here’s how hucksters are manipulating Google to promote shady Chrome extensions
summary:
- Google forbids third-party extension developers from manipulating extension presentation in the Chrome Web Store.

- Some extensions may appear in search results that are unrelated or abusive, misrepresenting their functionality.

title: Time to check if you ran any of these 33 malicious Chrome extensions
summary:
- At least 33 malicious browser extensions in the Chrome Web Store compromised 2.6 million devices for 18 months.
- Cyberhaven researchers found a malicious update on December 25 that allowed data theft from users who installed it.
- The malicious version (24.10.4) was pushed through a spear phishing email to developers.
- Other affected extensions were identified, totaling 19 having 1.46 million downloads.
- Organizations are encouraged to re-evaluate security protocols for browser extensions due to these vulnerabilities.

sources.title: Time to check if you ran any of these 33 malicious Chrome extensions

title: Widely used DNA sequencer still doesn’t enforce Secure Boot
summary:
- In 2012, an industry coalition adopted Secure Boot to protect devices against malware.
- Secure Boot uses public-key cryptography to prevent unauthorized code from loading.
- Microsoft requires Secure Boot for Windows devices, but not for specialized devices like the Illumina iSeq 100 DNA sequencer.
- The iSeq 100 can boot from legacy BIOS and uses outdated firmware with critical vulnerabilities.
- Firmware Read/Write protections are not enabled, allowing potential firmware modifications by attackers.
- The vulnerabilities could affect a broad range of devices using similar OEM motherboards.

sources.title: Widely used DNA sequencer still doesn’t enforce Secure Boot

title: Passkey Technology: Elegant but Not Usable Security
summary:
- Passkeys are a promising alternative to traditional passwords, aimed at enhancing security against phishing attacks.
- Despite widespread support across various platforms, the implementation of passkeys leads to confusion and inconsistencies in user experience.
- Issues arise from the competing workflows among different operating systems and browsers, making passkeys less user-friendly than intended.

sources.title: Passkey Technology: Elegant but Not Usable Security

title: India to make its first chip by October 2025 under plan

- Tata Electronics is constructing a semiconductor unit in Dholera, Gujarat, in collaboration with Taiwan’s Powerchip Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation.
- Micron's assembly and testing facility in Sanand, Gujarat, is reported to be 60% complete.
- The Indian government has allocated 334 crore rupees (approximately US$38.52 million) to IISc Bengaluru for research in gallium nitride technology, important for telecommunications and power sectors.

- The feature became available on the web on Feb. 15 and will expand to Mac, iOS, and Android soon.

- It achieved a score of 21.1% on Humanity’s Last Exam, outperforming Gemini Thinking (6.2%) and GPT-4o (3.3%), but below OpenAI’s Deep Research (26.6%).
- Unlike OpenAI’s $200 monthly subscription model, Perplexity offers a freemium model with limited free queries and unlimited access for subscribers.

title: Death of OpenAI whistleblower deemed suicide in new autopsy report

- Balaji previously accused OpenAI of [illegally using copyrighted material](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/10/23/technology/openai-copyright-law.html) to train AI models and provided critical documents for a lawsuit against the company.  
- He celebrated his 26th birthday shortly before his death and had plans for a nonprofit in machine learning.  
- His passing sparked discussions on [AI ethics and whistleblower dangers](https://x.com/elonmusk/status/1879796369038409877) in Silicon Valley.

title: UK Government Orders Apple to Create iCloud Backdoor for Encrypted Data Access
summary:
- The UK government secretly ordered Apple to create a backdoor for accessing users' encrypted iCloud data.
- The demand was made in January under the UK's Investigatory Powers Act 2016, requesting blanket access to all encrypted files.
- Apple may stop offering its encrypted cloud storage, Advanced Data Protection, to UK users due to this demand.
- A technical capability notice under the Investigatory Powers Act requires Apple to assist law enforcement globally.
- Apple's Advanced Data Protection service utilizes end-to-end encryption, meaning only account holders can decrypt files.
- Apple has stated it would refuse to build a backdoor and withdraw security features from the UK market instead.
- The UK government’s demand may lead to conflicts with EU data-sharing agreements.
- This move is part of a broader effort to enhance national security and public safety.
- Concerns about privacy and data security among users and technology experts are being raised in response to the demand.
- Critics fear this sets a dangerous precedent, potentially weakening security for Apple users worldwide and eroding civil liberties.
- Security experts warn that backdoors could be exploited by malicious actors, leading to identity theft and data breaches.
- The concept of a 'NOBUS' backdoor suggests only authorized agents would have access, but this is heavily criticized as a flawed idea.

sources.title: UK government demands Apple backdoor to encrypted cloud data: report
UK demands ability to access Apple users’ encrypted data
UK demands Apple backdoor for encrypted cloud data
UK’s secret Apple iCloud backdoor order is a global emergency, say critics
What is an encryption backdoor?

title: These Google Photos alternatives offer tons of storage options at a reasonable price
summary:
- Google Photos now offers only 15GB of free storage, down from unlimited free storage for images.
- Alternatives to Google Photos include:
  - **[Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/)**: 1,000 photos for free; paid plans start at $10.44/month for unlimited storage.
  - **[Dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/)**: 5GB free; paid plans start at $9.99/month for 2TB.
  - **[Ente](https://ente.io/)**: 5GB free, focuses on privacy; paid plans start at $2.49/month for 50GB.
  - **[Cryptee](https://crypt.ee/)**: 100MB free; paid plans start at $3.30/month for 10GB, includes document editor features.
  - **[Amazon Photos](https://www.amazon.com/Amazon-Photos/b?ie=UTF8&node=13234696011)**: 5GB free with Prime membership; paid plans start at $1.99/month for 100GB.
  - **[500px](https://500px.com/)**: Allows 21 high-resolution photos per week for free; premium plans start under $50/year.
  - **[Photobucket](https://photobucket.com/)**: No free storage; $5/month for 1TB.

title: The EV Tax Credit and Recent Legislative Changes
summary:
- Two bills introduced in the Senate aim to significantly increase electric vehicle prices.
- The Eliminating Lavish Incentives to Electric (ELITE) Vehicles Act would eliminate the $7,500 EV tax credit and other incentives, sponsored by Sen. John Barrasso.
- The Fair Sharing of Highways and Roads for Electric Vehicles (Fair SHARE) Act would impose a $1,000 tax on EV purchases, introduced by Sen. Deb Fischer.
- Both bills face potential opposition from some Republicans whose districts benefit from Biden’s EV investments.
- The $1,000 fee is designed to match gas taxes an average gasoline car owner would pay over ten years.

- The EV tax credit offers up to $7,500 off new electric vehicle purchases.
- Eligibility is based on various criteria including manufacturing location, battery sourcing, vehicle price, and buyer's income.
- The credit aims to promote energy security and reduce reliance on Chinese battery manufacturers.
- Automakers are moving to establish North American manufacturing to comply with the credit's requirements.
- The list of eligible vehicles changes frequently as the industry adapts to the new rules.
- Recent Senate bills aim to eliminate the credit and impose new fees on EV purchases.
- Hyundai, Kia, and Genesis vehicles have become eligible for the tax credit, reflecting ongoing industry adjustments.

title: Amazon to Remove Download Feature for Kindle Books Starting February 2025
summary:
- Amazon will remove the 'Download & Transfer via USB' feature on February 26, 2025, affecting how Kindle users back up their books.
- This feature allows users to download purchased books to their computers for backup or conversion to other formats.
- Users without Wi-Fi may find this feature useful as it provides offline copies of their books, especially in light of Amazon's history of removing titles remotely.
- The feature supports the AZW3 format for older devices; modern Kindles use KFX format, which has strict DRM protection.
- After the change, users can still use apps to send documents to Kindles via USB but cannot directly download purchased books to a computer anymore.
- Amazon has not provided a specific reason for the removal of this feature.

title: Kagi’s search engine adds a more private way to search
summary:
- Kagi introduces a new privacy feature called [Privacy Pass](https://blog.kagi.com/kagi-privacy-pass) for its search engine.
- Privacy Pass allows users to make searches without them being traceable to their identities.
- This feature uses an authentication protocol that generates tokens which cannot be linked back to the user.
- Kagi emphasizes the technical impossibility of tracking users while allowing them to search freely.
- Users can enable Privacy Pass in Kagi's Orion browser (available on macOS, iOS, and iPadOS), the Kagi app for Android, and in browser extensions for Firefox and Chrome.
- Kagi also supports access via Tor with a specific onion address but warns that without Privacy Pass, searches can still be linked to user accounts.
- Privacy Pass is available for $10/month Professional plan and $25/month Ultimate plan users, not included in free or $5/month Starter plans.

- GlobalWafers has not received notifications about potential subsidy changes under the US CHIPS and Science Act.
- The company states any modifications could impact future investments.
- In December 2024, US Commerce Department finalized $406 million in grants for GlobalWafers to enhance production in Texas and Missouri.
- Reports suggest the White House may renegotiate some awards, leading to concerns about delays in semiconductor subsidies.
- Recent developments include reviews of CHIPS Act subsidies with unclear terms and details of ongoing and upcoming investments.

title: Phase design platform raises $13m in funding
summary:
- Phase, a design platform for UI/UX designers, launched out of beta with $13 million in funding.
- The startup is based in Taipei and Berlin and received investments from Gobi Partners, 500 Global, 42CAP, and Palm Drive Capital.
- Founded in 2017, Phase offers a WYSIWYG platform for creating interactive simulations without manual coding and exporting production-ready UI code.

title: Indian Bollywood music labels sue OpenAI over song use
summary:
- OpenAI opposes Indian media groups joining a copyright lawsuit against it, filed on Feb. 11.
- Claims it did not use content from these groups to train ChatGPT.
- The original lawsuit was initiated by ANI last year for unauthorized use of its content.
- Other organizations like NDTV and the Indian Express have sought to join the case.
- OpenAI asserts it doesn't need partnership agreements for public data use.

- Major Bollywood music labels, including T-Series, Saregama, and Sony, are suing OpenAI in New Delhi.
- The lawsuit claims OpenAI used their sound recordings without authorization for training AI models.
- The Indian Music Industry (IMI) filed the petition on Feb. 13, alleging violations of copyright laws.
- This lawsuit is part of a larger trend of legal challenges against AI companies for unauthorized use of content.
- OpenAI maintains it operates within fair use guidelines, considering India its second-largest user market.

sources.title: OpenAI disputes copyright claims from Indian media groups
Indian Bollywood music labels sue OpenAI over song use

title: Taiwan’s chip tester sees growth despite US tariff risks
summary:
- Chunghwa Precision Test Technology (CHPT) expects minimal impact from potential US tariffs due to most operations in Taiwan.
- Expanded its San Jose subsidiary in 2022, increasing capacity fourfold to meet demand for AI chip and smartphone processor testing.
- North America accounted for 60% of revenue in 2023.
- President Scott Huang projects strong 2025 growth driven by AI and high-performance computing.
- For Q4 2024, CHPT reported a record net profit of NT$322 million (US$9.8 million) and annual net profit of NT$510 million (US$15.5 million).

title: White House reviews CHIPS Act subsidies, terms unclear
summary:
- The White House is reviewing projects under the US CHIPS and Science Act, which allocated US$39 billion to boost the US semiconductor industry.
- Officials are assessing subsidy agreements, but details on potential renegotiations are unclear.
- Taiwan’s GlobalWafers has received US$406 million for projects in Texas and Missouri and has not been informed of any changes.
- The subsidies are tied to milestones set for 2025.
- The review includes labor and childcare provisions added under Joe Biden, with possible adjustments for policy shifts.

title: Global disunity, energy concerns and the shadow of Musk: key takeaways from the Paris AI summit
summary:
- The Paris AI summit showcased global tensions regarding AI development among political and business leaders.
- US Vice President JD Vance emphasized a unilateral approach to AI, opposing global regulations and caution against collaborating with authoritarian regimes.
- Both the US and UK declined to sign a diplomatic declaration on AI governance, signaling a lack of consensus among major nations.
- Discussions included the environmental impact of AI and its potential to exacerbate global inequalities.
- The speed of AI progress was highlighted, with predictions that advanced AI systems could emerge within the next few years.
- China proposed collaboration for security and shared advancements in AI, despite its absence from the summit.
- Elon Musk's influence was felt at the summit due to a significant bid for control over OpenAI, raising concerns about the organization’s future.

sources.title: Global disunity, energy concerns and the shadow of Musk: key takeaways from the Paris AI summit

title: Apple collaborates with Alibaba and Baidu for AI launch in China amid trust disparities
summary:
- Trust in AI is significantly higher in China (72%) compared to the US (32%).
- India shows the highest trust level at 77%, while Ireland has the lowest at 24%.
- Gender differences are noted, with men (52%) being more trusting than women (46%).
- Younger individuals exhibit greater confidence in AI than older generations.
- Concerns over job losses (58%) and misinformation contribute to declining trust in AI and the tech industry.
- Edelman highlights the importance of transparent communication regarding AI's societal impacts.
- Apple plans to introduce AI features in China by mid 2025, adapting to local regulations.
- Collaborating with Alibaba and Baidu to develop AI technologies for Apple devices.
- Alibaba is creating a censorship system, while Baidu provides Visual Intelligence for information scanning.
- AI features will be exclusive to Apple devices in China.

sources.title: China trusts AI more than US: survey
Apple teams up with Alibaba, Baidu for AI launch in China

title: JioCinema and Disney’s Hotstar Merge into JioHotstar
summary:
- Hotstar and JioCinema have merged into a new platform called JioHotstar.
- The merger integrates JioCinema’s library into Disney’s Hotstar, offering extensive local content and over 100 TV channels.
- JioHotstar aims to attract more than 500 million users, providing content in 19 languages with various subscription plans.
- The merger consolidates major sports rights under one platform, including the Indian Premier League and FIFA World Cup.
- JioCinema's app will be phased out post-transition of existing subscribers to JioHotstar.

- JioCinema and Disney's Hotstar merged into JioHotstar on Feb. 14.
- The new platform combines JioCinema's library with Hotstar's content, featuring over 100 TV channels and programming from various studios.
- Subscription plans start at 149 INR (US$1.71) for an ad-supported option, and 299 INR (US$3.45) for an ad-free plan for up to four screens.
- The merger follows Reliance's acquisition of Disney's Indian assets worth US$8.5 billion, aiming to capture 85% of streaming viewers in India.
- JioHotstar will also stream significant sports events such as the IPL, ICC tournaments, Premier League, and FIFA World Cup.

title: MassMutual Ventures Faces Leadership Changes; New Tech Startup Fund Launched
summary:
- East Ventures and SV Investment have launched the "East Ventures South Korea Fund" aimed at tech startups in Southeast Asia and South Korea.
- The fund targets revenue-generating series A to B startups with investments between US$1 million and US$3 million.
- Final close of the fund is expected by mid-2025, anchored by Korea Development Bank.
- MassMutual Ventures' heads for APAC and Europe, Ryan Collins and Anvesh Ramineni, will leave the firm in Q2 2025.
- Douglas Russell will lead MassMutual’s operations in these regions, with potential sale or spin-out by end of 2024.
- Collins and Ramineni have invested in over 40 companies, managing around US$450 million in assets, focusing on digital health and fintech in their investment strategy.

- The Independent Workers’ Union of Great Britain (IWGB) supports the action, citing worsened conditions post-2021 court ruling on drivers’ rights.
- Uber denies claims of unfair pay and states most drivers earn more than the national living wage.
- Many drivers report struggling to meet their living expenses and feel exploited by low fare rates.

title: Samsung Considers Stargate AI Partnership Amid SoftBank's Q3 Loss
summary:
- SoftBank Group Corp. reported a 369.2 billion yen ($2.4 billion) loss for fiscal Q3, compared to a profit of 950 billion yen last year.
- Quarterly sales rose 3% year-on-year to 1.83 trillion yen ($11.9 billion).
- For the fiscal year so far, SoftBank recorded a profit of 636 billion yen ($4 billion), improving from a loss of 459 billion the previous year.
- Investment gains were noted from companies like [Alibaba](https://www.fastcompany.com/91277555/softbank-reveals-2-4-billion-loss-q3?partner=rss&utm_source=rss&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=rss+fastcompany&utm_content=rss), but some were reversed in the latest quarter.
- Samsung is considering joining the $500 billion [Stargate Project](https://www.techinasia.com/news/samsung-faces-tough-choice-over-stargate-ai-partnership), an AI initiative led by SoftBank, OpenAI, and Oracle.
- A meeting on Feb. 4 in Seoul with executives from SoftBank, OpenAI, and Samsung indicated potential collaboration.
- Samsung's advancements in AI chips may beneficially position it for the project, despite skepticism over funding and competition from Nvidia and TSMC.
- The initiative aligns with US AI strategy, creating increased pressure on Samsung to participate.

title: Dubai delivery app talabat reports strong 2024 growth
summary:
- Talabat Holding plc reports its first financials since its IPO in December 2024.
- GMV reached US$7.4 billion in 2024, up 23% from the previous year.
- Revenue grew to US$3 billion, a 32% year-on-year increase, with adjusted EBITDA up 55% to US$497 million.
- Net income surged 64%, reaching US$346 million.
- GCC market GMV rose 20% to US$6.3 billion; non-GCC markets grew 42% to US$1.1 billion.
- Food orders contributed US$5.5 billion with a 16% increase.
- Key drivers included higher consumer demand and a 25% increase in monthly active customers.
- For 2025, talabat anticipates GMV growth of 17-18% and revenue growth of 18-20%.

title: Chinese Apps and TikTok Return Amid Regulatory Changes
summary:
- TikTok is back in the App Store after a temporary removal due to a US ban.
- President Trump signed an executive order delaying TikTok's ban enforcement for 75 days starting January 20.
- TikTok's service providers face potential penalties for operating the app in the US.
- The Supreme Court upheld the TikTok ban law.
- TikTok offers a download option for its Android app outside of Google Play due to previous removal.
- Discussions of a potential Oracle and Microsoft deal to take over TikTok operations while ByteDance retains a minority stake.
- Apple and Google restored TikTok in the U.S. after over 25 days since its January 18 removal.
- Other ByteDance apps, CapCut and Lemon8, were also restored.
- TikTok started restoring services for existing users on January 19, but new downloads resumed only now.
- Trump ordered ByteDance to sell TikTok to a U.S. entity within 75 days.
- TikTok accounted for 52 million downloads in the U.S. last year, as per Sensor Tower data.
- After a five-year ban, Chinese apps are returning to the Indian market due to eased restrictions by the government.
- This decision may reshape the competitive landscape of mobile applications in India.

title: Car-sharing platform Getaround shuts down US operations

- The closure includes the shutdown of its HyreCar business acquired for US$9.45 million in 2023.
- US customers must return rented vehicles by Feb. 12 to maintain insurance coverage.
- Operations will continue in six European countries, including France, Germany, and Norway.
- The company raised over US$750 million in funding, including a US$300 million round from SoftBank in 2018.
- Went public via a SPAC merger in 2022 but faced financial difficulties, including delisting warnings and layoffs.
- An “orderly wind-down” of US operations was approved on Feb. 7, with most layoffs scheduled by Feb. 14.
- Shutdown costs are estimated between US$1.5 million and US$2 million.

title: TikTok's Return and Potential Acquisition by Oracle and Microsoft
summary:
- Oracle and Microsoft are negotiating to take over TikTok’s global operations.
- The deal would allow ByteDance to keep a minority stake, with Oracle overseeing data and algorithm management.
- This agreement aims to reduce Chinese ownership of TikTok.
- Microsoft’s role in the talks remains unclear; it previously participated in a 2020 bid along with Walmart, which is not involved this time.
- News follows a recent executive order from President Trump providing TikTok a 75-day reprieve from enforcement actions regarding its operations in the U.S.
- TikTok has been restored in the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.
- The app was banned in the US for nearly a month prior to its return.
- US Attorney General Pam Bondi assured Apple that it wouldn't face fines for hosting the app.
- The removal followed a law banning apps from ByteDance, TikTok's parent company.
- Despite an executive order from President Trump not enforcing the ban for 75 days, Apple and Google initially refrained from hosting the app due to potential penalties.

title: FBI’s warrantless ‘backdoor’ searches ruled unconstitutional
summary:

• The case involved Agron Hasbajrami, whose emails were obtained without a warrant. 
• In 2023, the FBI conducted over 57,000 searches of US person data, a 52% decrease from 2022.
• The ruling declares warrantless searches unreasonable and calls for a legislative warrant requirement to protect citizens’ rights.

title: Tech Companies Roll Back Diversity Initiatives Amid Political Backlash
summary:
- Google eliminates its diversity hiring targets and will review its DEI programs.
- This decision follows a trend among tech companies to roll back DEI initiatives amid criticism from conservative groups.
- DEI targets introduced in 2009 aimed for a 30% increase in underrepresented hires by 2020.
- Google's 2024 diversity report shows minimal change in leadership demographics, with 5.7% Black and 7.5% Latino representation.
- Reconsideration of diversity report publication and adaptation of programs due to legal changes is underway.
- Google's SEC filing omits previous commitments to diversity, equity, and inclusion.
- Other companies, like Meta and Amazon, have also ended DEI programs amid similar pressures.
- Pinterest identifies DEI attacks as potential business risks in its [latest 10-K filing](https://d18rn0p25nwr6d.cloudfront.net/CIK-0001506293/973659c6-d9a4-483b-a151-22b4a2a5bd9e.pdf).
- Insufficient or excessive DEI efforts could harm talent acquisition and brand reputation.
- Target faced backlash and a lawsuit for not disclosing DEI risks, affecting its stock price.
- Google removed cultural events like Black History Month and Pride Month from the default calendar in mid-2024.
- Other events removed include Jewish Heritage, Indigenous Peoples Month, Holocaust Remembrance Day, and Hispanic Heritage Month.
- Users can still add other important moments manually to their calendars despite these removals.
- OpenAI removed its diversity, equity, and inclusion commitment page, redirecting it to a new page emphasizing people with different backgrounds.
- The previous commitment stated a serious and ongoing investment in DEI, captured by [Internet Archive](https://web.archive.org/) and cited by [CNN](https://www.cnn.com/2023/12/15/tech/openai-board-diversity/index.html).
- The change likely took place between January 22 and January 27, 2025, coinciding with a trend among tech companies distancing from DEI language due to political backlash.
- OpenAI has not commented on whether internal processes have changed following this removal, while still maintaining a page on [fairness](https://openai.com/index/evaluating-fairness-in-chatgpt/) in its model training.

sources.title: Google ditches DEI hiring goals
Google scraps diversity hiring goals and cites Trump’s DEI orders
Mark Zuckerberg’s charity insists it’s not abandoning its DEI efforts
Academic researchers are going to have to learn algospeak

- Deepfakes have led to misinformation and financial fraud, prompting calls for regulations against AI impersonation.

title: Apple Investigated by German Watchdog for Potential Antitrust Violations
summary:
- Germany's antitrust watchdog, Bundeskartellamt (FCO), is investigating Apple's app privacy framework since 2022.
- FCO suspects Apple may not treat third-party app developers equally, potentially amounting to self-preferencing.
- New regulations under the Digital Markets Act prohibit self-preferencing by big tech on iOS and core platform services like the App Store.
- The investigation focuses on Apple's App Tracking Transparency framework, which treats third-party tracking permissions differently than its own.
- Concerns were raised about unequal treatment in consent dialogues and the strict application of tracking definitions against third-party apps.
- Apple is given the opportunity to respond to the FCO's findings prior to any formal advocacy or acting on it.
- The German antitrust authority has charged Apple with abusing its market power through its app tracking tool.
- This investigation follows three years of scrutiny regarding Apple’s App Tracking Transparency feature.
- The feature has faced criticism from Meta Platforms and app developers for making it difficult for competitors to access user data relevant for advertising.
- Apple has defended its feature as a means to enhance user privacy.
- If Apple does not address concerns, it risks daily fines and may face further proceedings.

sources.title: Apple’s app tracking privacy framework could fall foul of German antitrust rules

title: EU’s Disinformation Code moves closer to becoming DSA benchmark

- Signatories must take actions like removing financial incentives for disinformation and focusing on service integrity, such as eliminating bots and fake accounts.
- Controversy arises as platforms like Meta have weakened their commitment to fact-checking while remaining signatories of the Code.
- The Commission has endorsed this integration, which will lead to auditable commitments by the stated date.

title: Collaboration Between Financially Motivated Hackers and Espionage Groups Amid Ongoing Threats from China's Salt Typhoon Hackers

- Exploited vulnerabilities in Cisco devices, aiming to breach over 1,000 globally.  
- US government has sanctioned firms associated with Salt Typhoon but expects continued attacks.

- Tools from previous Chinese espionage linked to attacks in Southeastern Europe and Asia from July to January.  
- Speculation exists about financial motives or cover-ups for espionage activities, although this behavior is atypical for Chinese threat actors.

- Foxconn aims to establish a cooperative relationship with [Nissan](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=nissan) rather than acquiring the company.
- Chairman Young Liu stated, 'Purchasing its shares is not our aim; our aim is cooperation.'
- Liu mentioned that acquiring a stake in Nissan could be considered if it facilitates collaboration.
- Foxconn isn't seeking to acquire Nissan but is open to collaboration and may consider a stake for partnership support.
- This is Foxconn's first public confirmation of talks with Nissan, which is looking for new partnerships after ending merger discussions with Honda.
- Foxconn is expanding into electric vehicles while focusing on design and manufacturing, not becoming a branded automaker.
- Following Liu's remarks, Nissan shares fell 6% and Foxconn shares dropped 1.1%.

sources.title: [Foxconn](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=foxconn) seeks Nissan partnership in EVs
Foxconn eyes collaboration over acquisition with Nissan

summary:

title: SailPoint's $1.38 Billion IPO Marks Significant Return to Public Markets
summary:
- SailPoint, a cybersecurity company, has launched an IPO with a valuation of $11.5 billion.
- The IPO involves selling 47.5 million shares at a price range of $19 to $21, aiming to raise $1 billion.
- Previously public, SailPoint was taken private by Thoma Bravo in 2022 for $6.9 billion.
- It reports $813 million in annual recurring revenue and $395 million in net losses as of January 2024.
- SailPoint intends to use IPO funds to address over $1 billion in debt and support operations.
- The IPO is crucial for tech startups and venture capitalists seeking market insights.
- SailPoint priced its IPO at $23 per share, ultimately raising $1.38 billion.
- The company sold 60 million shares, resulting in a $12.6 billion valuation.
- This marks SailPoint's return to the public market after more than two years since its privatization in 2022.
- Thoma Bravo acquired SailPoint in 2014 and took it public in 2017.

title: Coinbase Plans to Re-Enter India Seeking Regulatory Approval
summary:
- Coinbase is planning to re-enter the Indian market after ceasing operations over a year ago.
- The company is engaging with the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) for necessary approvals to operate in India.
- Previous launch in 2022 was halted due to lack of recognition from India's National Payments Corporation.
- Coinbase aims to comply with regulatory requirements while exploring global expansion.
- The crypto market in India is small, impacted by tax regulations introduced in 2022.
- A potential re-entry could help fill the gap left by the collapse of the Indian exchange WazirX.
- CEO Brian Armstrong cited “informal pressure” from the Reserve Bank of India for the previous suspension.
- The Indian cryptocurrency market faces challenges such as a 30% tax on crypto income and a 1% transaction deduction.
- A Coinbase spokesperson confirmed intent to comply with regulations without sharing specifics on the FIU process.

title: Elon Musk to Withdraw OpenAI Nonprofit Bid if Board Agrees to Terms
summary:
- Elon Musk offered to buy OpenAI’s governing nonprofit for $97.4 billion.
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman humorously rejected the offer, referencing a previous Twitter acquisition.
- Musk's bid comes amid OpenAI's plans to convert to a for-profit structure, complicating their process.
- OpenAI's board may view Musk’s offer as a hostile takeover or question his funding.
- OpenAI’s counsel stated the nonprofit is not for sale and is valued at much more than Musk's bid.
- Musk’s ongoing lawsuits against OpenAI add tension to the situation.
- Elon Musk will withdraw his $97.4 billion bid for OpenAI’s nonprofit if the board agrees to halt its conversion to a for-profit corporation.
- Musk's filing to the U.S. District Court emphasizes that the offer is serious and insists on preserving the charity’s mission.
- OpenAI’s board quickly rejected Musk's bid as it does not value the nonprofit and asserts that it is not for sale.
- Musk has previously sued OpenAI, claiming anticompetitive behavior and fraud.

title: What can we learn from insulin price reductions
summary:

- GoodRx partnered with Sanofi to offer Lantus insulin for $35, illustrating effective collaboration in healthcare.
- Despite insulin price reductions, overall prescription drug costs have risen nearly 40% since 2014, and many Americans struggle to afford their medications.
- GoodRx is expanding affordability efforts to other chronic conditions through partnerships to reduce costs for diabetes medications and continuous glucose monitors.

title: Why your IoT devices are the weakest link in security
summary:
- IoT devices are projected to reach 40 billion by 2030, but face an average of 10 attacks per device daily.
- Security breaches in critical sectors like healthcare and utilities may lead to severe consequences.
- Many IoT devices lack essential security features like encryption, leading to vulnerabilities.
- Users and manufacturers share responsibility for IoT security, with manufacturers often prioritizing time-to-market.
- Regulatory frameworks are essential for enforcing security standards in IoT devices.
- AI and machine learning can enhance security by predicting and preventing threats, but require proper integration.

sources.title: Why your IoT devices are the weakest link in security

title: OpenAI pledges that its models won’t censor viewpoints

summary:

title: EU abandons ePrivacy, AI liability reforms as bloc shifts focus to AI competitiveness
summary:
- The EU Commission has officially withdrawn the ePrivacy Regulation proposal due to a lack of agreement among co-legislators.
- This move is part of the Commission's 2025 work program, citing no foreseeable agreement and the proposal being outdated in light of recent technological and legislative changes.
- The ePrivacy Directive aims to strengthen online privacy protections, but years of lobbying from tech giants like Google and Amazon stalled its progress.
- Other significant changes include the withdrawal of the AI Liability Directive, which aimed to update product safety rules for AI technology.
- The Commission is now focusing on fostering AI competitiveness, with plans for an Innovation Act and Cloud and AI Development Act among its legislative priorities.

- In addition to current capabilities, Softr plans to add workflows and tables in the future to enhance app-building functionalities.

title: Apple Chips Vulnerabilities Allow Data Leak from Browsers
summary:
- Apple-designed chips in Macs, iPhones, and iPads have two vulnerabilities leaking sensitive data from Chrome and Safari.  
- Vulnerabilities enable side channel attacks via speculative execution optimizations, affecting A- and M-series chip sets.  
- The more significant attack, FLOP, can read sensitive data like location history and credit card info from targeted sites.  
- SLAP is limited to reading adjacent strings from another webpage.  
- Affected devices include recent Mac laptops, desktops, iPads, and iPhones since 2021.  
- Researchers suggest potential mitigations and await patch plans from Apple, although Apple claims there's no immediate risk.

sources.title: Apple Chips Vulnerabilities Allow Data Leak from Browsers

title: Authorities Arrest Four Suspected [8base Ransomware](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=8base) Operators Amid Global Takdown Campaign
summary:
- Ransomware payments fell by over a third to $813 million in 2024, down from $1.25 billion in 2023.
- Major incidents included attacks on NHS trusts and Krispy Kreme.
- Decline attributed to victims refusing to pay and intensified law enforcement actions against [cybercriminals](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=cybercrime).
- Total payments for 2024 are lower than previous years, below 2020's $999 million and 2019's $1.1 billion.
- Expert Jacqueline Burns Koven suggests this indicates averted 'ransomware apocalypse' due to effective collaboration and victim resistance.
- Despite the decline, ransomware attacks are still frequent, with rising demands from cyber gangs.
- UK ministers are considering a ban on ransomware payments by public entities, proposing mandatory reporting of such payments.
- Payments dropped more than 35% in 2024, with hacker demands 53% higher than actual payments in the second half of the year.
- Law enforcement efforts successfully targeted major ransomware groups like BlackCat and Lockbit in 2024, contributing to payment declines.
- International law enforcement agencies seized the 8base ransomware gang's dark web leak site.
- The operation involved agencies from Europe, Japan, U.S., and U.K., coordinated by the Bavarian State Criminal Police.
- 8base is linked to RansomHouse and employs double-extortion tactics, demanding ransom while threatening to expose sensitive info.
- The group targeted multiple sectors, especially healthcare, and was linked to a cyberattack on the United Nations Development Programme.
- The takedown message was confirmed by the U.K.'s National Crime Agency.
- A global operation arrested four Russian nationals linked to over 1,000 ransomware attacks.
- The operation, named “Phobos Aetor,” occurred in Phuket, Thailand, targeting the 8base ransomware group.
- The suspects are accused of amassing $16 million through ransomware attacks on 17 organizations in Switzerland.
- Over 40 pieces of evidence have been seized and more than 100 servers linked to the criminal network were taken down.
- The FBI warned that Phobos ransomware targeted critical infrastructure in the U.S.
- Charges were unsealed against two suspects, Roman Berezhnoy and Egor Nikolaevich Glebov, for operating the 8base affiliate organization.

sources.title: Global ransomware payments plunge by a third amid crackdown
Ransomware payments dropped in 2024 as victims refused to pay hackers

title: Backdoor Infecting VPNs Uses Stealthy Magic Packets for Attacks
summary:
- Ivanti VPN networks are under active attack exploiting the critical vulnerability [CVE-2025-0282](https://arstechnica.com/security/2025/01/ivanti-vpn-users-are-getting-hacked-by-actors-exploiting-a-critical-vulnerability/).
- This vulnerability allows complete control over network-connected devices with no authentication required.
- A security patch was released, upgrading Connect Secure devices to version 22.7R2.5.
- Attackers exploit this vulnerability to install new malware packages, DRYHOOK and PHASEJAM.
- PHASEJAM creates a web shell for remote access and simulates the upgrade process to deceive administrators.
- SPAWNANT malware is also used to disable Ivanti's integrity checker for device files.
- Researchers revealed a new backdoor, J-Magic, affecting enterprise VPNs using Juniper's Junos OS.
- The backdoor remains dormant until it receives a 'magic packet', which includes a challenge encrypted with an RSA key.
- J-Magic only exists in memory, making it harder to detect and has been identified in 36 organizations' networks.

sources.title: Ongoing attacks on Ivanti VPNs install a ton of sneaky, well-written malware
Backdoor infecting VPNs used “magic packets” for stealth and security

title: Apple and Google take down malicious mobile apps from their app stores
summary:
- Apple and Google removed 20 malicious apps from their app stores after Kaspersky's report.
- The malware, called SparkCat, has been active since March 2024 and was found in a food delivery app and 19 other unrelated apps.
- SparkCat was downloaded over 242,000 times and could capture recovery phrases for cryptocurrency wallets, enabling theft of funds.
- Google confirmed that it has banned the developers of the affected apps and protected Android users with Google Play Protect.
- The compromised apps were also found on non-official app stores despite being pulled from official platforms.

sources.title: Apple and Google take down malicious mobile apps from their app stores

title: AI chatbots distort and mislead when asked about current affairs, BBC finds
summary:
- Leading AI assistants like ChatGPT, Copilot, Gemini, and Perplexity create distortions and inaccuracies when responding to current affairs.
- Over 50% of AI-generated answers showed significant issues according to BBC research.
- Errors included misstatements about politicians' positions and incorrect health advice from the NHS.
- 20% of responses had factual errors; 13% of sourced quotes were incorrect or fabricated.
- BBC's Deborah Turness warned about the risks of AI tools undermining public trust in facts.

sources.title: AI chatbots distort and mislead when asked about current affairs, BBC finds

- The chip design is expected to be completed in a few months, with production planned in collaboration with TSMC, targeting mass production by 2026.
- The custom chip aims to strengthen OpenAI's position with suppliers and enhance its infrastructure.
- The team, led by Richard Ho, a former Google executive, has expanded to 40 members and is collaborating with Broadcom.

title: Elon Musk bids nearly $100bn for OpenAI as Macron calls for AI regulation reforms in Europe
summary:

title: [Carta](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=carta) settles two more lawsuits that alleged sexual harassment and discrimination
summary:

- On January 9, 2025, Carta settled a lawsuit from former sales manager Alexandra Rogers, who claimed she was groped by the company’s CRO, Jeff Perry, and subsequently fired for reporting it.
- The company also settled a complaint from former account executive Amanda Sheets in November 2023, who alleged discrimination and retaliation regarding her disability accommodations.
- Carta denies wrongdoing in both cases, and the settlements were made without admission of liability.
- These incidents add to past scrutiny over the treatment of women at Carta, following previous allegations of workplace inequality and a toxic culture.

title: Bird cuts 120 jobs as part of ‘strategic realignment’
summary:

- Bird aims to position teams closer to customers in the Americas and Asia, expanding its market reach.
- The layoffs were said not to focus on cost reductions; instead, they reflect changes driven by AI integration.
- Affected employees will receive transition support, specific severance details were not disclosed.

title: Apple fixes iPhone and iPad bug used in an ‘extremely sophisticated attack’
summary:
- On February 10, 2025, Apple released updates for iOS 18.3.1 and iPadOS 18.3.1 addressing a security flaw potentially exploited in targeted attacks.
- The vulnerability allowed disabling USB Restricted Mode on locked devices, which blocks data transfer via USB connections if the device remains locked for over seven days.
- Security researchers suggest the attack required physical access to use forensic tools like Cellebrite or Graykey.

- Broadcom has reportedly increased VMware prices by 3–6x, with some customers experiencing price hikes as high as twentyfold.
- The migration process from VMware to other platforms is expected to be complex and costly, taking 18 to 48 months for large-scale migrations.
- VMware support concerns have arisen since Broadcom's acquisition, with users reporting difficulties accessing timely assistance.

summary:

- The summit is focused on discussing the future of AI amidst rapid developments in the field, including the U.S.'s $500 billion Project Stargate.
- This is the third major summit on AI governance, aiming to foster diplomatic dialogue and address the societal impact of AI, despite criticism about the speed of government responses to private sector advancements.

summary:

- Led by General Catalyst, the initiative seeks to reduce regulatory complexities which hinder AI adoption.
- Key figures attending include French President Emmanuel Macron and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.
- The initiative emphasizes collaboration between established companies and startups in the European tech ecosystem.

title: Revel nabs $60M in New York State funding to build more EV chargers
summary:
• Revel secured a $60 million loan from NY Green Bank to expand its EV charging network in NYC.
• This loan marks the first investment by NY Green Bank in EV charging infrastructure.
• The funding will allow Revel to build nine new sites, adding 267 fast-charging stalls by 2027, with five sites planned to be completed within the next 12 months.
• Upcoming sites include charging stations at JFK and La Guardia airports.
• The Maspeth station will feature 60 stalls, making it one of the largest in the country.
• New York State mandates all new light-duty passenger vehicles to be zero emissions by 2035.
• Revel is also seeking to expand into California, aiming to launch a site in the Bay Area soon.

- India’s Modi is cohosting the summit to involve more global actors and prevent a U.S.-China AI rivalry.

title: Lyft to launch Mobileye-powered robotaxis ‘as soon as 2026,’ starting with Dallas
summary:
- Lyft plans to introduce fully autonomous robotaxis powered by Mobileye as soon as 2026, starting in Dallas.
- The announcement comes before Lyft's Q4 and full-year 2024 earnings report, coinciding with Waymo’s plans for a commercial robotaxi service.
- Marubeni, a Japanese conglomerate, will finance the Mobileye-equipped vehicles for Lyft's app.
- Lyft aims to scale its operations to thousands of vehicles across multiple cities after launching in Texas.
- Mobileye’s technology is integrated with vehicles from multiple OEMs including Ford and General Motors.
- Lyft has faced challenges in the autonomous vehicle sector, including previous partnerships that did not materialize as expected.
- The partnership with Marubeni is crucial for Lyft’s asset-light business model, which relies on effective fleet management.

title: Roblox joins $27 million industry nonprofit to support online safety
summary:
- Roblox, Google, OpenAI, and Discord cofound nonprofit Robust Open Online Safety Tools (ROOST).
- ROOST will fund free, open-source tools for online safety in internet businesses.
- Roblox has implemented measures to restrict inappropriate messaging for its 85 million daily active users, utilizing AI and automation for real-time monitoring.
- An open-source AI model developed by Roblox detects various forms of disallowed content and supports multiple languages, with further development expected by 2025.

title: AI's Impact on Inequality and Supply Chain Optimization: Highlights from Paris Summit
summary:
- Pendulum offers an AI-driven platform to help enterprises optimize supply and demand based on fragmented data sources.
- Co-founder Benjamin Fels emphasizes the importance of precise supply demand management for sustainability and profit.
- The company rebranded from Macro-Eyes before a funding round of $22 million, focusing on expansion and product enhancement.
- Notable customers include Adore Me and the U.S. Department of Defense.
- Jean-François Gagné joins as chief strategy and product officer, adding expertise from his background at Element AI.
- The company stands out due to its algorithmic approach developed over a decade, addressing the fragility of supply chains exacerbated by the pandemic.

- The global summit in Paris discusses AI's effects on environment and inequality, attended by leaders and tech experts.
- Anne Bouverot highlights the unsustainable energy demands of AI while also promoting its potential to mitigate climate change.
- Christy Hoffman warns that AI without worker involvement could exacerbate inequality across democracies.
- Max Tegmark compares the current situation to the film 'Don’t Look Up', stating that awareness of AI's risks is being ignored.
- The Paris gathering, termed the AI action summit, contrasts with the previous AI safety summit in the UK.

sources.title: Pendulum’s AI-driven platform helps enterprises better predict supply and demand
Engine of inequality: fears over AI’s global impact dominate Paris summit

title: AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li warns policymakers not to let sci-fi sensationalism shape AI rules
summary:
- Fei-Fei Li addressed the Artificial Intelligence Action Summit in Paris, advocating for a balanced AI ecosystem that includes academia and community involvement.
- She emphasized the necessity for AI policies based on scientific evidence rather than sensationalism in sci-fi narratives.
- Li warned against ideologically-driven governance and called for practical approaches to harness AI's potential while minimizing harmful impacts.
- She believes the current era will be noted for its significant civilizational implications and stresses the importance of informed decision-making by policymakers and AI leaders.

sources.title: AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li warns policymakers not to let sci-fi sensationalism shape AI rules

title: ByteDance releases open-source generative model VideoWorld
summary:
- ByteDance’s Doubao AI team has launched VideoWorld, a new video generative model, on GitHub in collaboration with Beijing Jiaotong University and the University of Science and Technology of China.
- VideoWorld features 300 million parameters and distinguishes itself by independently acquiring knowledge without relying solely on textual or tagged input data.
- The model excels in performing complex tasks such as origami folding and bow tying, demonstrating improved intuition.
- Researchers evaluated the model through scenarios including a Go game for rule learning and reasoning, as well as robot simulations for planning and manipulation, with training enhanced by video demonstrations for future frame prediction.
keywords: University of Science and Technology of China

sources.title: ByteDance releases open-source generative model VideoWorld

title: Media giant Lee Enterprises confirms cyberattack as news outlets report ongoing disruption
summary:
- Lee Enterprises confirmed a cyberattack that disrupted operations at numerous newspapers across the U.S.
- CEO Kevin Mowbray stated the company is working to restore systems post-attack.
- A spokesperson confirmed the outages were due to a cybersecurity event, but did not disclose specific details about the attack or affected information.
- Some newspapers experienced changes to their editions, while others reported being unable to build pages and publish.
- Lee Enterprises recently reported earnings of $144.6 million for the fiscal first quarter but did not mention the cyberattack in the earnings announcement.

summary:

title: OpenAI to Open First Office in Germany's Munich
summary:
- OpenAI to open its first office in Germany, specifically in Munich, in the coming months.
- Announcement made by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, highlighting Germany's technical expertise and innovation.
- OpenAI has been in discussions with German officials about the office since 2023, noting Germany has the highest number of users and developers in Europe.
- Germany is the largest market for OpenAI in Europe, with the highest number of users, paying subscribers, and developers.
- The decision follows discussions with German officials since 2023, supported by Germany Trade & Invest.
- This aligns with a trend of tech giants like Apple and Google expanding in Germany.
- The Munich office will complement existing locations in Paris, Brussels, and Dublin, underscoring the region’s importance in the AI sector.

title: Defense firm Anduril in talks for $2.5b, valued at $28b
summary:
- Anduril Industries is in talks to secure US$2.5 billion in funding.
- This funding could value the company at over US$28 billion.
- Led by venture capital firm Founders Fund, this follows a recent US$1.5 billion investment.
- The company is known for developing autonomous weapon systems and plans to invest nearly US$1 billion in a manufacturing facility in Ohio, covering an area similar to 87 football fields.
- No comments were provided by representatives of Anduril or Founders Fund regarding the funding discussions.

title: Indian edtech lender raises $2.9m bridge funding
summary:
- Eduvanz raised 25.52 crore rupee (US$2.9 million) in bridge funding.
- Funding co-led by Juvo Ventures and Capria Fund, with participation from Peak XV Partners and Unitus Ventures.
- Funds will be used for working capital, product development, and marketing.
- 26,405 compulsorily convertible preference shares issued at 9,667 rupee (US$110.12) each on Feb. 1.
- Founded in 2016, Eduvanz provides online education loans, raising nearly US$49 million to date.

title: Taiwan’s Economic Growth Driven by AI and Tech Demand Amid Export Boom
summary:
- Taiwan's economy grows due to increasing demand for AI and technology.
- Economic outlook is uncertain due to external factors.
- Tech industries significantly contribute to GDP and economic stability.

- Exports increased by 4.4% year-on-year, reaching $38.71 billion in January.
- This is the 15th month of consecutive growth, exceeding forecasts.
- Imports decreased by 17.2% year-on-year to $28.74 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $9.97 billion.
- Strong demand for AI and high-performance computing drives the tech sector.
- China and Hong Kong are major export markets but saw an 11.7% decline.
- February export estimates by the MOF range from $36.5 billion to $37.7 billion, a potential 16-20% year-on-year increase.

sources.title: Taiwan’s economy grows on AI, tech demand amid uncertainty
Taiwan’s exports hit $38.71b as tech boom

title: Meta to lay off 5% of workforce
summary:
- Meta Platforms will begin layoffs on Feb. 10, affecting approximately 5% of its workforce.
- Notifications will start at 5 am local time in various regions, including the US, followed by Europe, Asia, and Africa between Feb. 11 and Feb. 18.
- Employees in Germany, France, Italy, and the Netherlands are excluded from the layoffs due to local labor laws.
- The layoffs are referred to as “performance terminations,” focusing on the “lowest performers.”
- The company plans to speed up hiring for key roles like machine learning engineers from Feb. 11 to March 13 to support its 2025 strategy goals.

sources.title: Meta to lay off 5% of workforce

title: Coinbase must face New York lawsuit over securities sales
summary:
- A US federal judge ruled that Coinbase must face a lawsuit from customers claiming unlawful sales of securities.
- The decision was made by District Judge Paul Engelmayer on February 7.
- The judge rejected Coinbase’s argument of not being a "statutory seller" under federal law.
- The lawsuit includes claims under state laws in California, Florida, and New Jersey.
- The case was initially dismissed in February 2023 but was partially revived in April 2024 by the 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals.
- Coinbase is also facing legal action from the US SEC regarding unregistered securities trading.

sources.title: Coinbase must face New York lawsuit over securities sales

title: Elon Musk Clarifies He Is Not Interested in Acquiring TikTok
summary:
- Elon Musk stated he is not interested in acquiring TikTok during an interview at the WELT Economic Summit on January 28.
- These comments follow reports of potential deals involving Musk and TikTok after a delayed law requiring parent company ByteDance to sell or ban the app in the U.S.
- Musk has not put in a bid for TikTok and is unfamiliar with the platform, indicating he would analyze its algorithm if he were involved.
- He emphasized that acquiring companies is not typical for him, with his purchase of Twitter (now X) being an exception.
- His statements come amid scrutiny of TikTok by the US government due to national security concerns, with potential decisions expected in February.

sources.title: Elon Musk said he’s not interested in acquiring TikTok
Elon Musk says he has no plans to buy TikTok

title: Trump Ends Legal Battle Over Twitter Ban and Meta Expands AI Assistant to MENA, Supporting Arabic Users
summary:
- Meta has launched its AI assistant, [Meta AI](https://www.techinasia.com/news/meta-expands-ai-assistant-to-mena-supports-arabic-users), in the MENA region including UAE, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Morocco, and Iraq.
- The assistant is integrated into Meta’s apps and users can activate it via a blue circle icon or by saying "@Meta AI" in group chats.
- It supports Arabic to enhance accessibility and may include image editing and personalized portraits in future updates.
- Currently, it serves 700 million people in 42 countries and supports 13 languages globally.

- President Donald Trump has ended his lawsuit against [Twitter](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/08/trump-ends-legal-battle-over-twitter-ban/), which banned him after the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot.
- A federal judge dismissed Trump's lawsuit in 2022, and a recent court filing proposed to dismiss the case altogether.
- Elon Musk reinstated Trump's account on Twitter (now known as X), and Meta settled a similar lawsuit by agreeing to pay $25 million for Trump's bans on Instagram and Facebook.

sources.title: Meta expands AI assistant to MENA, supports Arabic users
Trump ends legal battle over Twitter ban

title: Apple’s new research robot takes a page from Pixar’s playbook
summary:
- Apple released a research paper illustrating the importance of expressive movements in human-robot interaction.
- The study references Pixar’s Luxo Jr. as an example of non-anthropomorphic design, using a lamp in their research.
- A video showcases the expressive movements of the robot, suggesting potential functionalities similar to smart speakers like HomePod.
- The research is part of Apple's efforts to develop a more advanced smart home system with expressive robotic capabilities.
- Future products may incorporate designs that are less humanoid, leveraging non-anthropomorphic forms like lamps.

sources.title: Apple’s new research robot takes a page from Pixar’s playbook

title: Google Maps' Evolution and Advances in AI Technology
summary:
- Google's Gemini 2.0 Pro Experimental AI model announced, improving factuality, coding, and mathematics.
- Early preview available for Gemini Advanced users; Gemini 2.0 Flash model released for all.
- Tim Cook praises DeepSeek’s AI for driving efficiency; Apple uses a hybrid AI model.
- Concerns over OpenAI's role in training DeepSeek's models; Apple may work with other AI companies.
- DeepSeek’s AI models are competitively priced but raised efficiency training questions.
- AI feature rollout has not boosted iPhone sales, which have seen a slight decline.
- Google Maps launched on 8 February 2005, now with over 2 billion monthly users.
- Google acquired Where 2 Technologies, the precursor to Google Maps, in 2004.
- Development included AJAX for dynamic map updates; Stephen Ma emphasizes collaboration.

Apple CEO says DeepSeek shows ‘innovation that drives efficiency’

title: Ex-Meta Employee Sues for Sexual Harassment and Gender Discrimination
summary:
- Kelly Stonelake, a former Meta director, filed a lawsuit against the company in Washington for sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation.
- She alleges ongoing harassment from 2009 until her layoff in January 2024, including unwanted physical contact and coercion for promotions.
- Despite reporting the harassment, Meta reportedly took no action, contributing to Stonelake's ongoing mental health issues and her medical leave for PTSD at the time of her layoff.
- The lawsuit includes claims of retaliation for raising concerns about a product and being overlooked for promotions in favor of male colleagues.

sources.title: Early Meta Employee Sues for Sexual Harassment, Gender Discrimination
Ex-Meta Employee Sues for Sexual Harassment

title: AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li says AI policy must be based on ‘science, not science fiction’
summary:
- Fei-Fei Li, a leading figure in AI, emphasizes the importance of grounding AI policy in reality rather than futuristic fiction.
- She warns against viewing AI systems as having intentions or consciousness, urging a focus on current technologies instead.
- Li advocates for pragmatic policy-making that encourages innovation while minimizing unintended consequences.
- She stresses the need for policies that support open access to AI resources, particularly for academic and research institutions with limited resources.
- These insights were shared ahead of the AI Action Summit in Paris, highlighting three key principles for future AI policymaking.

sources.title: AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li says AI policy must be based on ‘science, not science fiction’

title: Autodesk CTO Raji Arasu calls for diversity in the teams building AI
summary:
- Raji Arasu, CTO of Autodesk, emphasizes the importance of diversity in AI development teams.
- She has utilized AI for decades to address complex software challenges, particularly with unstructured data.
- Arasu highlights the need for women and individuals from diverse backgrounds in strategic decision-making roles.
- Her career includes significant roles at Oracle, eBay, StubHub, and Intuit before joining Autodesk.
- AI presents risks such as biases and data privacy issues, which need to be tackled through collaborative efforts between industry and government.
- Ethical design in AI development should incorporate diverse perspectives and governance frameworks to minimize bias.
- Continuous monitoring, accountability, and customer collaboration are essential for ensuring AI benefits society.

sources.title: Autodesk CTO Raji Arasu calls for diversity in the teams building AI

title: Ai2's Tulu3-405B AI Model Outperforms DeepSeek and the Importance of Open Source Spirit
summary:
- Ai2 released Tulu3-405B, claiming it outperforms DeepSeek V3 and OpenAI’s GPT-4o.
- The model features 405 billion parameters, trained on 256 GPUs, and is open source and freely available.
- Tulu3-405B aims to strengthen U.S. leadership in open-source AI, providing a competitive alternative to DeepSeek.
- It achieved top results in benchmarks like [PopQA](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/30/ai2-says-its-new-ai-model-beats-one-of-deepseeks-best/) and [GSM8K](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/30/ai2-says-its-new-ai-model-beats-one-of-deepseeks-best/), surpassing several models in its class.
- The model is available for testing via Ai2’s web app, with training code accessible on [GitHub](https://github.com/).
- The concept of 'open source' is often debated, with the Open Source Initiative (OSI) involved in validating licenses.
- Discussions focus on companies placing features behind paywalls and the transparency of development processes.
- The culture and governance of open source projects are crucial in addition to legal definitions.
- The Android Open Source Project exemplifies these concerns, particularly around Google's control and community engagement.
- Experts caution that projects owned by a single vendor may lack genuine open source attributes.
- The rising significance of open source in AI is noted, with calls for transparency in models like DeepSeek and Meta's Llama.
- Regulatory pressures, such as the EU AI Act, are reshaping definitions of open source, prompting companies to reconsider its meaning.

sources.title: Ai2 says its new AI model beats one of DeepSeek’s best
Why the ‘spirit’ of open source means much more than a license

title: Christie’s announces AI art auction, and not everyone is pleased
summary:
- Christie’s is set to hold its first art auction dedicated to AI-generated works on February 20, 2025.
- The event, called ‘Augmented Intelligence,’ includes pieces from artists like Mat Dryhurst, founder of Spawning AI.
- A live-painting robot will be the centerpiece at the Rockefeller Center galleries in New York.
- Critics are concerned about AI tools being trained on artists' works without consent, arguing it undermines traditional artists.

sources.title: Christie’s announces AI art auction, and not everyone is pleased

title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Elon Musk's 'Doge' Team from Accessing Treasury Records
summary:
- A federal judge has blocked Elon Musk’s 'Doge' team from accessing sensitive treasury department records.
- The injunction follows a lawsuit by 19 Democratic attorneys general against the Trump administration.
- The lawsuit alleges violation of federal law regarding unauthorized access to the payment system vital for managing tax refunds and benefits.
- Immediate destruction of any downloaded sensitive information by unauthorized individuals was ordered by the judge.
- A hearing on this matter is scheduled for February 14.
- New York AG Letitia James raised concerns over security and potential illegal financial freezes due to Doge’s treasury access.
- Critics highlight Musk's influence on government data access and spending, while supporters advocate for efficiency.
- Allegations within the lawsuit claim Doge's operations could disrupt Congress-approved funding and compromise data protection laws.
- Musk’s efforts to reshape the federal government are inciting political chaos.
- The Doge team comprises wealthy executives, far-right ideologues, and inexperienced young engineers.
- Key federal agencies involved include the Department of Treasury, GSA, and USAID, with claims of unauthorized data access.
- Musk is seen to have significant control over Doge, with backing from Donald Trump.
- Influential figures in Musk's ventures lead the initiative, raising ethics and legality questions.
- Far-right political influences are reported to shape the group's operations, with connections to the Trump administration.

sources.title: Judge temporarily blocks Musk’s ‘Doge’ team from accessing treasury records
Who is helping Elon Musk gut the US government?

title: Apple's Potential Partnership with DeepSeek to Advance AI and Smart Glasses Innovation in China
summary:
- DeepSeek's open-source AI models enhance China's smart glasses industry by lowering costs and improving capabilities.
- Focus on integrating AI into augmented reality (AR) eyewear.
- Rokid's DeepSeek-R1 is more affordable than OpenAI’s GPT-4.
- Rokid launched AR glasses with large language models in November 2024, featuring real-time translation and navigation.
- Limiting AI service access due to demand; surpassing Doubao as China’s fastest-growing AI app with 22.2 million daily active users.
- DeepSeek's AI capabilities challenge perceptions of American tech giants like OpenAI and Google.
- Partnering with DeepSeek could benefit Apple, enhancing access to the crucial Chinese market for iPhone sales.
- Apple aims for integration of Apple Intelligence into services but faces regulatory challenges, prompting collaborations with local AI providers.

sources.title: DeepSeek boosts China’s smart glasses innovation
How Apple could work with DeepSeek to pull ahead in the AI race

title: Elon Musk's Political Influence and Beliefs
summary:
- Elon Musk has invested over $250 million in support of Donald Trump's re-election, gaining political influence.
- His ‘Department of Government Efficiency’ (Doge) has clashed with federal workers and led to the ousting of officials.
- Musk aims to dissolve the US Agency for International Development (USAid) without evidence of corruption, threatening opposition.
- Post-Trump's inauguration, Musk’s team has rapidly taken control of multiple agencies, causing chaos.
- The legitimacy of Doge's operations is questioned, with lawsuits regarding its authority.
- Musk's alignment with far-right politics raises questions about his beliefs and intent.
- He has recruited young tech workers for governmental roles, bypassing standard clearances, impacting government efficiency.
- Musk's views are inconsistent, supporting both universal basic income and anti-union policies, often influenced by personal business interests.
- Personal issues, especially concerning his daughter, have influenced his political direction.

sources.title: How Elon Musk Wields Political Power Over the US Government
What does Elon Musk believe?

summary:

title: Trump Administration Suspends $5bn Electric Vehicle Charging Program
summary:
- The Trump administration ordered US states to suspend a $5bn electric vehicle charging station program.
- The Federal Highway Administration issued a memo stating no allocation funds under the Biden administration's NEVI program should be spent.
- Emily Biondi, FHWA’s associate administrator, noted that existing guidelines are rescinded and new plans must be approved before new obligations can occur.
- Reimbursements for current obligations will be allowed to maintain financial commitments.
- As of November, there are 126 public charging ports at NEVI stations in nine states, showing an increase in operational EV stations.

sources.title: Trump Administration Suspends $5bn Electric Vehicle Charging Program

title: Amazon Scales Back Diversity Initiatives in Favor of AI Investments
summary:
- Amazon removed references to ‘inclusion and diversity’ from its 2024 10-K report.
- The sentence emphasizing investment in inclusion and diversity was reduced to a focus on being 'Earth’s best employer.'
- These changes follow similar actions by other tech companies like Google and Meta, amid increasing scrutiny of DEI programs by conservative groups and the Trump administration.
- Amazon has removed references to diversity and inclusion in its 2024 annual report after scaling back several DEI programs.
- Last year’s report highlighted diversity, but the latest focuses on becoming “Earth’s best employer.”
- Public policies streamlined, with DEI mentions condensed and terms like “transgender” removed from the webpage.
- Candi Castleberry, VP of inclusive experiences, announced the discontinuation of outdated DEI programs.
- This change is part of broader industry trends; some firms have cut DEI efforts while others maintain them.
- Amazon plans to invest US$100 billion in AI development by 2025, indicating a strategic shift in focus.

sources.title: Amazon deletes ‘inclusion and diversity’ language in latest filing
Amazon scales back diversity efforts, focuses on AI

title: Delhivery names ex-McKinsey exec as chief business officer
summary:
- Delhivery appointed Vani Venkatesh as chief business officer (CBO), effective Feb. 28, 2025.
- Venkatesh will manage transportation businesses, client servicing, and marketing functions.
- She has over 20 years of experience, previously serving at Airtel, McKinsey & Company, and Hindustan Unilever Limited.
- Venkatesh was most recently the chief marketing officer at Airtel until December 2024.
- Delhivery, founded in 2011, is a major logistics provider in India, serving D2C brands and B2B enterprises across 18,600 pin codes.

sources.title: Delhivery names ex-McKinsey exec as chief business officer

title: Ikea-backed Livspace names new CEO, moves HQ to India
summary:
- Livspace has appointed co-founder Ramakant Sharma as the new CEO, succeeding Anuj Srivastava, who will become chairman of the board.
- Sharma will manage daily operations while Srivastava will focus on the IPO process and strategic growth.
- Livspace is moving its headquarters from Singapore to India.
- The company has operated since 2014 and has become a unicorn after raising $180 million in a Series F funding round in 2022.
- To date, Livspace has raised over $433.38 million from notable investors including KKR & Co and Ikea.
- This leadership change follows layoffs of over 100 employees in 2023 as part of cost-cutting measures.

sources.title: Ikea-backed Livspace names new CEO, moves HQ to India

title: Meta and UNESCO Collaborate to Enhance AI for Underrepresented Languages
summary:
- Meta is partnering with UNESCO to launch the Language Technology Partner Program aimed at improving AI for speech recognition and translation.
- The program focuses on gathering speech recordings and transcriptions for underrepresented languages, requiring over 10 hours of content.
- Key partners include the government of Nunavut, which is supporting efforts for languages like Inuktut.
- An open-source machine translation benchmark has been released to evaluate language models, covering seven languages and available on Hugging Face.
- These initiatives are positioned as philanthropic, while also aiming to strengthen Meta's AI capabilities.

sources.title: Meta launches new program to improve speech and translation AI
Meta, UNESCO expand AI for underrepresented languages

title: Pinterest shares jump 20% on AI ad boost, strong Q1 forecast
summary:
- Pinterest shares surged 20% on Feb. 7, following a forecast of Q1 revenue between US$837 million to US$852 million, exceeding analyst expectations.
- Adjusted core earnings projection ranges from US$155 million to US$170 million.
- Growth driven by AI-powered advertising tools, reducing advertiser input by 50% and enhancing competitiveness.
- In Q4, Pinterest reported record revenue of US$1.15 billion due to strong advertising demand across various sectors.
- Stock historical volatility noted, with a 14% drop in November after weak projections but a 21% increase after strong results in April 2024.

title: Canada bans DeepSeek chatbot on gov’t devices
summary:
- The Canadian federal government has banned the DeepSeek chatbot on government devices due to privacy concerns.
- The ban is a response to the app's collection and retention of sensitive personal data.
- Chief Information Officer Dominic Rochon recommended federal departments limit its use.
- Shared Services Canada has blocked the app on all devices it controls.
- This follows a similar initiative in the US regarding security risks associated with DeepSeek.
- The decision aligns with Canada's earlier move to remove TikTok from government devices over data collection issues.

title: Trump admin freezes EV charging program that gave Tesla millions
summary:
- The Department of Transportation has paused funding for a $5 billion EV charging infrastructure program, affecting Tesla which received at least $31 million from it.
- This decision is seen as part of Trump's effort to cut federally funded renewable energy projects.
- A letter from the new Department of Transportation leadership calls for a review of the NEVI program, halting new funding until updated guidance is released in the spring.
- The NEVI program, included in the Bipartisan Infrastructure Act, had an appropriation of $1 billion annually from 2022 to 2026.
- Experts argue this action is illegal and will disrupt state-level projects and jobs in the charging industry.

title: ‘It just didn’t go the way I planned’: Hawk Tuah girl breaks silence after crypto scandal
summary:
- Haliey Welch, known as the Hawk Tuah girl, speaks out after cryptocurrency scandal in December 2024.
- She launched $HAWK memecoin on December 4, achieving a $490 million market cap before collapsing by $440 million in 20 minutes.
- Welch describes trusting a friend in the token launch, which she regrets as her biggest mistake, and expresses sorrow for those affected.
- FaZe Banks, who previously urged her to fire her team, revealed he agreed to a podcast appearance with conditional terms regarding market manipulation and the future of $HAWK.
- A leak from Welch’s team caused the podcast episode to be canceled unexpectedly, leading to fluctuating prices for $HAWK.

sources.title: ‘It just didn’t go the way I planned’: Hawk Tuah girl breaks silence after crypto scandal

title: Shopify pushes for ‘open trade’ as Trump delays import exemption
summary:
- Shopify published a blog post advocating for ‘open trade’ amidst President Trump's delay in ending a trade exemption on certain Chinese imports.
- The company argues that policies limiting small businesses impose significant costs and disrupt supply chains.
- The de minimis rule, allowing low-cost imports to enter the U.S. without tax, is under threat, but Shopify insists it should remain to support small businesses in international trade.
